Comment to classify: The Florida Association of Livestock Markets supports the comments made by LMA on this proposed rule.

We appreciate USDA's engagement of stakeholders in this commenting process and hope that adjustments are made based on the feedback.

We're particularly interested in seeing changes to the market duties in the approved livestock marketing facility agreement to avoid situations where markets are taking on a policing role or being asked to agree to things they legally cannot do - such as not allowing a livestock owner to ship cattle.

We also hope USDA backs away from the proposed ADT changes relating to Farm of Origin.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: April 15, 2015

To Whom It May Concern:

The following are the comments of the Pennsylvania Livestock Marketing Association on the proposed rule regarding Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities (Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018).

We thank you for the chance to provide feedback on the proposed rule. While we appreciate the time and effort taken to update the regulatory scheme surrounding Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities, we feel that USDA missed the mark in components of this proposed rule that reduces ADT rule flexibilities for cattle moving to an Approved Livestock Marketing Facility. The proposal limits the flexibility to only cattle coming to the facility from a Farm of Origin. Additionally, defining Farm of Origin to the farm where livestock are produced or maintained for at least four months prior to movement is unnecessarily broad restricting movement even more.

In Pennsylvania, most of our livestock markets do business with out-of-state customers on a regular basis. This is both a function of being a smaller state and of cattle movement patterns. Additionally, many of our customers selling at market are small producers who bring just one or a few head of cattle to market at a time. For these small producers, it would be extremely expensive to have to have a veterinarian visit the farm to write a health certificate, especially when you consider the fact the cost of this health certificate could only be spread out over a few animals at the most.

This added expense could drive producers to sell at a different market just to avoid crossing state lines. They also may consider selling out of the market environment where it is less likely animal health and livestock movement requirements.

This would lead to less traceability rather than more traceability.

Sincerely,

Pennsylvania Livestock Marketing Association

Comment to classify: The industry desperately needs these changes! As a Livestock Market operator in southern Michigan since 1956, we have seen many changes over the years, notably a decrease of Livestock Marketing options. We have several customers from northern Ohio that choose us to market their slaughter cattle. Requiring to have an IVCI issued by a vet for each consignment of slaughter cattle would not only be costly, but not necessary. These cattle go to slaughter and are inspected by USDA at their destination for harvest. To be an "Approved USDA Livestock Facility" to accept out of state slaughter cattle and be required to have a Vet at the site on sale days would serve no purpose. Our local vet on call would allow his/her services on the farms and not pin him/her down at our premise for 6 hours each sale day. These out of state consignments are currently and would be continued to be USDA back tagged, penned separate, not co mingled, and sent from our facilities to slaughter. In addition, they are individually identified with RFID or USDA approved metal ear tags. An "Owner-Shipper" statement to accompany the cattle is no problem for the farmers or truckers. These changes are a step forward to allow livestock marketing across state lines, and will enhance disease traceability.

Randy Heselschwerdt, Napoleon Livestock Commission Co. Comment to classify: Dear Mr. Shea,

As the association representing local livestock auction markets in the state of South Carolina, we are writing to provide comments on the proposed rule regarding Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities (Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018).

Generally, we support the comments submitted by Dan Harris, president of the national Livestock Marketing Association. In particular, we share his concerns with the Farm of Origin changes to the ADT rule limiting the feasibility of us continue to do business with our out-of-state customers. Adult cattle coming into our markets are documented and inspected upon arrival, so this adjustment is unnecessary.

We also feel strongly that the agreement should remain in the regulation so markets have the ability to formally comment on any changes just as we are doing now.

In addition, we agree that the language in the proposed agreement should be adjusted so it is clear livestock markets are not solely responsible for all livestock movement and animal health requirements. Our producers, veterinarians, and animal health officials also play an important role.

Our final comment is unique to South Carolina. We have state inspectors that attend each of our livestock auctions. We feel this resource market owners should be able to be utilize, if they chose to do so, to help address the shortage of private veterinarians and increase traceability. This could be accomplished by allowing these state inspectors the ability to write health papers or alternative movement documents to keep livestock moving.

If you have any questions about these comments, please contact John Kissee at 770-596-0128.

South Carolina Livestock Marketing Association

Comment to classify: To whom it may concern,

I am a law student in my final year of law school at Nova Southeastern University in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Your proposed rule stood out to me as I had previously taken an animal law seminar in which I wrote a paper focusing, in part, on the interstate transportation of rodeo broncs. In doing so, I spoke about the federal Twenty-Eight Hour Law (49 USC 80502) as well as the regulations adopted by the United States Department of Agriculture as mentioned in 9 C.F.R. 89. Noticing that your proposed rule overlaps with much of research I encountered in writing my paper, I would offer the following comments as to the proposed revision to Part 71.
I understand the practicality of your decision to revise 71.20 as simply requiring a veterinarian on-call rather than on the premise at all times, however I am concern that the language in this section is too board as to who determines whether an animal may need an interstate certificate of veterinary inspection (ICVI) before leaving the facility after sale. For example, should this determinate be left up to someone who profits financially from having these animals shipped to another facility despite their health conditions, I have serious concerns for its vague phrasing.
Further, the restatement in 71.20(a) of 8303 of the Animal Health Protection Act (AHPA, 7 U.S.C. 8301 et seq.) stating that APHIS may carry out operations and measures to control, or eradicate any pest or disease of livestock also seems rather ambiguous. I understand that should pests or disease be detected in livestock, there is a strong health and safety interest in having them eradicated, however being a strong animal welfare advocate I would simply ask that this be done as humanely as possible by adding said language to your restatement.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: The West Virginia LMA is the trade association of local livestock markets located across West Virginia.

We would like to thank USDA for the work put into this proposal and the opportunity for industry feedback.

There are many positive pieces of the proposal. These include the ability to have veterinarians on call, the use of existing documents as owner shipper statements, and consolidating terminology to the single, more descriptive, term of "approved livestock marketing facilities."

At the same time, there are some pieces that could be improved through adjustments. In particular, the appeals process should be strengthened not weakened. Also, markets should not lose the ability to make formal comments on changes to the requirements listed in the agreement. This right would be lost if the agreement language was taken out of the regulation.

We hope adjustments can be made in these areas.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: The Georgia Livestock Markets Association supports the comments made by Livestock Marketing Association regarding this proposed rule. In particular, our feedback includes:

Support for the ability to use an existing document rather than an owner shipper statement
Opposition of the Farm of Origin component added to the ADT rule
Support for USDAs proposal to allow a veterinarian be on call rather than present during the sale.
Support for LMAs recommendations for changes to the Approved Livestock Marketing Facility agreement language
Strong preference that this agreement language remain in the regulations rather than a separate document

Thank you for the opportunity to provide feedback.

Sincerely,
Georgia Livestock Markets Association

Comment to classify: To Whom It May Concern:

I am writing to provide comments on USDAs proposed changes to the Approved Livestock Marketing Facilities and Animal Disease Traceability regulations (Docket No. APHIS-2014-0018).

As the President and CEO of Clovis Livestock Auction, Im concerned about a couple pieces of this proposal. One major concern I have is with the market duties in the proposed Approved Livestock Marketing Facility agreement. To me, it seems USDA would like markets to serve as the police of animal movement requirements. This is a government role that should not be passed on to private businesses. While we work with our buyers and sellers to help them meet requirements by having a veterinarian at our market, enforcing regulations is not a role markets should have to take on. The markets duties in the Approved Livestock Marketing Facility agreement should be adjusted to reflect this.

I also am concerned about the portion of the proposed rule making changes to what is required to bring adult beef cattle and dairy cattle of any age across state lines to an Approved Livestock Marketing Facility. Our auction market is located in eastern New Mexico, close to the Texas border. Due to this, we have many customers crossing state lines to sell or buy cattle.

Under the proposal, out-of-state producers selling cattle 18 months of age or older would have to get a health certificate before bringing these cattle to sell at our market, unless the cattle are coming from the farm where they are born or have been for four months. Getting a veterinarian to visit a farm and write a health certificate can be expensive. In this rule, USDA has recognized that access to large animal veterinarians is a very real problem. My concern is that USDA could be driving customers away from selling out our market by requiring health certificates prior to arrival. This is unnecessary as we have a veterinarian at our market and also record needed traceability information when cattle arrive.

I believe the farm of origin piece of the rule would have a negative impact on my business and put livestock markets that happen to be located close to a state line at a competitive disadvantage. Because of this, my strong recommendation is that USDA does not move forward this component of the proposed rule.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Charlie Rogers Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Charles Rogers --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify: Not sure if this relates directly to the proposed changes, but two points:

1) The ADT Rule has created a potential "traceability loophole" in allowing cattle to move interstate to an approved tagging site with no ID and no CVI. This should happen only if the receiving tagging site is required to tag with official ID and maintain records in such a manner that animals are traceable back to the state and ship-from location. For example, Virginia allows breeding age cattle to be imported with no ID and no CVI if they are moving to an approved market and tagging site in VA, but they require that cattle are tagged with 840 RFID and usually a back tag that can be correlated with seller/buyer records in market files. The 840 tag provides traceability going forward; the back tag provides backward traceability.

2) It is difficult to get dairy calves/steers tagged with official ear tags at Virginia markets due to number of animals handled. If these animals are moving to other states in a fairly direct manner (similar to cull cattle), back tags may provide adequate traceability if correlated with seller/buyer records on both ends (shipping and receiving locations). Current back tags could (if appropriate) also be scanned with bar code readers to improve efficiency and accuracy of data capture. For example, dairy calves/steers in VA tagged with back tags and correlated to seller/buyer records; animals could be tagged with ear tags in receiving state, which should be correlated with VA back tags. Back tags are cheap, unique when paired with a date and location, stay on fairly well for short-term movements and are easier to capture than metal tags. Comment to classify:
As to back tag placement: The most effective placement is in the hollow behind the shoulder. When placed back by the hip if a cow is mounted prior to the glue drying the tag is often dislodged. Tags also stay much better in the spring when animals are sheading if a curry comb is used to remove loose hair prior to application. Having worked the tagging chute at an auction yard for 3 years prior to my 26 year veterinary career where I have used numerous back tags I have found this to be the most effective placement.

Comment to classify: March 7, 2015

VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION
Bureau of Indian Affairs
Attn:Elizabeth K. Appel, Director, Office of Regulatory Affairs & Collaborative Action, Indian Affairs, U.S. Department of Interior,

Subject:Comments on Proposed Amendments to Regulations Governing the Housing Improvement Program. Fed. Reg. 2014-30692, Docket Nos. BIA-2014-0004-0001

I am Navajo and Apache. I have a Master in Public Affairs (MPA) from the Woodrow Wilson School of International & Public Affairs at Princeton University, where I studied domestic policy. Currently, I am studying Law at UC Hastings in San Francisco. I strongly support the proposed rule changes.

The addition of ranking factors for homelessness, overcrowding, and dilapidated housing will serve as positive steps towards the goal of better prioritizing the allocation of these limited resources. In addition, allowing applications to remain active for four years as opposed to the current one year, will enable the BIA to have a better sense of the current housing needs without the concern that less sophisticated applicants would fall off the waiting list while their housing needs remain unmet. The growing waitlists remains a serious concern and until additional resources are made available to meet these needs, these steps are necessary to best meet the needs of those most at risk.

Rural tribal communities have some of the highest poverty rates, unemployment rates and adolescent suicide rates of any communities in the United States. Providing quality long-term housing is a prerequisite for familial stability as well as wealth creation. As such, I fully support the proposed changes identified above.
Respectfully submitted,

Angelo Isaac Sandoval,
M.P.A. | J.D. Candidate

Comment to classify: The Housing Improvement Program from the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe would like to submit a comment to the proposed rule change of the Housing Improvement Program regulations, regarding the increase in the age requirement from 55 years of age to 62 years of age. For the record we oppose any change to this rule. The rationale for the proposed rule change, stated thusly, "To provide Tribes with flexibility to better address lengthy waiting lists of Tribal members awaiting housing assistance," does not serve the interests of the membership of the CRST. Lengthy waiting lists are a result of, and demonstrate the needs of our constituent population. In short, more funding for the BIA Housing Improvement plan would constitute a more rational solution to the issue of lengthy waiting lists currently maintained by Tribes.

We oppose the proposed rule change regarding points awarded to households with disabled members. This rule change does not take into account the fact that households with two disabled members. This rule change does not take into account the fact that households with two disabled members often experience high mortality rates. Situations where one disabled member deceases before the household is served may put the household at a distinct disadvantage in future funding cycles. We would like to keep this rule unchanged. Comment to classify: The United South and Eastern Tribes, Inc. (USET) is pleased to provide the Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA or the Bureau) with the attached comments on the Proposed Rule that would revise current regulations at 25 CFR Part 256, Housing Improvement Program (HIP).

USET is a non-profit, inter-Tribal organization representing 26 federally recognized Indian Tribes from Texas across to Florida and up to Maine. USET is dedicated to enhancing the development of Tribal nations, to improving the capabilities of Tribal governments, and assisting USET Member Tribes in dealing effectively with public policy issues and in serving the broad needs of Indian people.

Given the important role that the HIP plays in addressing the unmet housing needs of low-income American Indians, USET is pleased that the Bureau recognizes the need for updates and improvements to the program. However, we have concerns related to a number of the proposed changes, especially in light of the HIPs limited appropriation. In addition, we note that the Proposed Rule does not address the HIPs funding formula methodology, which does not currently function well for USET Tribes.

USET appreciates the opportunity to provide comments on the Proposed Rule and looks forward to the opportunity to provide additional input as rulemaking proceeds. Should you have questions or require additional information please do not hesitate to contact Ms. Liz Malerba, USET Director of Policy and Legislative Affairs, at (202)-624-3550 or by e-mail at Lmalerba@usetinc.org.

Comment to classify: March 6, 2015

Elizabeth K. Appel
Director, Office of Regulatory Affairs & Collaborative Action, Indian Affairs
U.S. Department of the Interior
1849 C Street, NW
Mail Stop 3642-MIB
Washington, DC 20240
Re: Comment Letter on Proposed Housing Improvement Program Regulation Amendments

Dear Ms. Appel:
As Executive Director of the Cheyenne River Housing Authority I am hereby submitting comments on the proposed Housing Improvement Program Regulation Amendments.

Addition of Category D Adding this new category of housing will help Tribes promote the benefits of homeownership to families of all ages. The down payment assistance funds will help Native American families qualify for homeownership financing. Since this is a new category and expands the allowable HIP Programs housing assistance funds and services there should be clarification that these funds may be used for: down payment assistance, closing costs, education in financial literacy and homebuyer education and counseling.
oIncome Eligibility for Category D In order to insure that the HIP down payment assistance is available to families who can afford mortgage financing, we recommend that income eligibility be defined for Category D by using the definition provided by the Native American Housing Assistance and Self-Determination Act (NAHASDA) regulations. This would allow eligibility by participants with annual income that is 80 percent of the area median income or United States median income, whichever is higher. (12 CFR 1000.10)

oPrevious Assistance While we recognize the need to serve clients who have not previously received assistance through the HIP program, we recommend that the restriction from being eligible for the HIP down payment program not apply to recipients of Category B rehabilitation funds if the funds were received prior to a certain time, e.g. more than 25 years ago (proposed Section 256.6 (g)).

oSet-Aside In order to promote the use of the down payment assistance program, we recommend that 10 percent of each Regions HIP allocation be set-aside for Category D. If the funds are not expended by the end of the fiscal year, they could be reprogrammed for other HIP categories. It is important to document need for Category D so future appropriation requests can be increased to meet the need to assist Native American families with down payment assistance.

Ranking Factors I support adding the new ranking factors of homelessness, overcrowding, and dilapidated housing will help identify the housing needs of the poorest of the poor. Comment to classify: March 6, 2015

VIA ELECTRONIC SUBMISSION
Bureau of Indian Affairs
Attn:Elizabeth Appel, Director, Office of Regulatory Affairs & Collaborative Action

Subject:Comments on Proposed Amendments to Housing Improvement Program, Docket Nos. BIA-2014-0004

My name is Christina Sturdevant and I am a first year law student in California.

First, the proposed amendment to the Housing Improvement Program that will increase the income guidelines fits squarely within the Bureau of Indian Affairs mission. The Bureau of Indian Affairs mission is to enhance the quality of life, promote economic opportunity, and to carry out the responsibility to protect and improve the trust assets of American Indians, Indian tribes, and Alaska Natives. If the income guidelines are increased from 125 percent to 150 percent of the federal poverty level, more American Indian and Alaska Native families will be eligible for the housing improvement grants. Individuals living at 150 percent of the federal poverty level, while slightly more advantaged than those living at 125 percent of the poverty level, still require adequate housing conditions. The increase of 25 percent will allow families who do not have financial resources to repair or renovate their existing homes.

Second, the Act should be amended to increase the monetary limit of funding granted to Category A and Category B recipients. Category A and Category B recipients currently receive a maximum of $2,500 to repair or renovate their homes. As stated in the proposal, this amount is inadequate to create material changes to the existing homes of impoverished families. Of course, any funding creates a dent, but $2,500 is unlikely to make any lasting improvements. For example, re-carpeting a small apartment costs at least $1,000. Surely, the Bureau of Indian Affairs mission to enhance the quality of life of American Indians, Indian tribes, and Alaska Natives is only minimally carried out by such a small repair. While an apartment may be re-carpeted, there might be termite damage (several thousands of dollars to repair), water damage, and any host of costly repairs that need fixing. A grant of merely $2,500 simply is not enough to truly enhance the quality of life of these families. Further, these amendments will advance the requirements of 25 U.S.C. 13, which state that, the Bureau of Indian affairs use money appropriated to them by Congress to assist in the relief of distress and conservation of health of Indians throughout the United States. This proposed amendment would improve the health of impoverished Native American families by improving basic needs. Comment to classify:
I believe that the EA was done very thoroughly and it covered many aspects that needed to be covered. The EA mentioned that the construction, maintenance, a decommission of the wind mills will have no significant impact on air quality standards especially with comparison to the air quality that already exists in the area. It is important to point out that if successful, this project could lead to the cutting down of NOx, CO2, and PM 2.5 emissions in the area due to coal powered electricity. However, I do not know the standards and data that was used to determine that the air quality in the project areas would not be affected by the projects emissions. My concern is based on what data was used to determine that the air quality in the project areas would not be affected by the project. If the data was based on a yearly basis there average would be skewed due to the fact the summer months, especially at Virginia Beach, there is an increased amount of Tourism that leads to an increase of CO2 emissions as well as other harmful substances into the air. So why does this matter? The locals are already used to their air quality decreasing during the summer months because of the tourists but how would this project affect the other 8-9 months out of the year? Will it get better or will get worse? Other than this concern, I support this project and believe that it should continue so that wind technology will advance and create a more sustainable way of living.

Comment to classify: January 16, 2015

Comments on the Environmental Assessment for Virginia Offshore Wind Technology Advancement Project on the Atlantic Outer Continental Shelf Offshore Virginia
AGENCY: Bureau of Oceans Management

Comments:
I do not oppose this project but want to be sure that it is done well, from an environmental standpoint. This EA describes reasonably good details on many issues that need to be covered. However there appear to be some gaps that I wish to bring to your attention that should be addressed:

1.The EA report says on page 82 the applicant has proposed that pile driving will occur in May. Then on page 109 the EA says pile driving will occur May through July. Which is correct?

2.Please be more specific about the aviation safety lights (page 67) that will be used. These need to be the most bird-friendly aviation safety lights known, which should be based on studies that have been supported by US Fish and Wildlife Service. My understanding is that white strobe lights are the least likely to attract birds during inclement weather (which is when this issue is most critical). This should be explicitly stated in the EA, and required in the turbine procurement specifications.

3.It is important that Dominion Virginia Power carry out post-construction monitoring during operation of the project to evaluate actual impacts from the wind turbines on birds, as stated on page 67. Post-construction monitoring is important to verify whether a problem really exists, to improve impact predictions from future scaling-up of wind power development in the area, and to guide any adaptive management that might be warranted. The EA should specify how the findings from post-construction monitoring would be used to improve operation of the wind turbine facility, as needed. BOEM should require Dominion Virginia Power to make all the post-construction monitoring data readily available to the public.

4.There appear to be some contradictions between the EAs description of the onshore impact area from all onshore construction activities (Section 3.2.4.2, page 71) versus the photo shown at: https://www.dom.com/corporate/what-we-do/electricity/generation/wind/virginia-offshore-wind-technology-advancement-project. Specifically, in this photo (section titled Onshore Interconnection), the cable right-of-way appears to be cutting through a forested area and a wetland. Meanwhile, the EA (Section 3.2.7.2, page 122) states that no clearing of native vegetation is expected during construction along the route of the onshore cables. Which version is correct?

5.Please describe in more detail the vegetation and the land cover of the onshore impact area.

What a wonderful proposal!  As a resident of the Hampton Roads area of Virginia, I have long awaited the movement of alternative energy sources, especially at the coastal areas of our country.  While studying Environmental Science 20 years ago, energy alternatives were in the spot-light, yet so little has been done in this time frame to take advantage of the wind, solar, and hydrological resources available to us.  Growing up in Southern New Jersey, Atlantic Electric took a giant leap by installing 5 wind turbines on Atlantic City's skyline and they've been going strong for many years. I commend these efforts to get our country out of the "stone-ages" of producing energy. Comment to classify: Dear Program Manager:

As a coastal resident, I am pleased that clean energy exploration is being considered off the Virginia shore. As a result of offshore farms, countries like England and Denmark are setting generation records. In Denmark last year wind produced 39% of energy consumed. Meanwhile, with the exception of a small, scaled floating turbine in Maine, the US, has no significant offshore wind capacity.

The twin turbine demonstration project is essential to investigate the potential costs and consequences of developing large-scale farms. The environmental assessment is sufficient for this small -scale project and should be approved so that we can begin to transition away from polluting and water intensive conventional energy forms.

In addition to reducing our carbon footprint and protecting water resources, wind has proven to be a resilient energy resource. During extreme events like drought, heat waves, storms and even tsunamis, when conventional power has shut down, wind continues to supply energy.

Theres no question that we need this energy source. And in general the public supports it. A Harvard scientist found that nearly 90% of Americans want to see more solar and wind energy added to the U.S. landscape.

Lastly, offshore wind development brings industry and high paying jobs. With the potential upside provided by offshore wind development, we cannot fail to investigate.

Please see that the environmental review process is expedited.

Comment to classify: 1. Table 2 of the VOWTAP EA indicates a projection of up to 464,000 km and 75,000 hrs of geophysical survey lines along the Atlantic Coast. This represents an invaluable opportunity to deploy ship-board profiling wind Lidar units to collect data for resource assessment and model validation. These data sets would be invaluable in reducing uncertainty for AEP estimates and improving numerical weather prediction models for day-ahead production forecasts and for vessel operation (O&M) planning and safety. Recent research at UMBC has confirmed the feasibility of ship-board Lidar deployment for weather model validation. See attached white paper for a discussion of the methodology, experiment and results.

2. As a general comment, I would stress that the risks and impacts to marine mammals from geophysical surveys for OSW development are much lower than O&G exploration and development since O&G requires much deeper bottom penetration and much higher sound pressure levels. I strongly support development of OSW and oppose O&G development for this and many other reasons.

3. Section 3.1.1.6 - No Action Plan. Even though this is only an EA, it would be great to see a preliminary estimate of reduction in annual CO2 emissions with the project, which would not occur under the No Action Plan. Comment to classify: Virginia Beach's economy is linked exactly to the environment and its health - from offshore fishing that feeds both locals and visitors to the beaches that make our homes worth so much money, provide a tax base through assessment of property value to the sunbathers who flock our stores and restaurants, parks and bike trails - the environment is the draw. Virginia Beach because of its location and dependence on the environment should be leading the way on sustainability and alternative energy sources. Oil may be plentiful and cheap but the downside and the potential to cripple our billion dollar tourist trade is too valuable to jeopardize. That might be okay for the gulf coast but no one goes to a beach with tar balls and dead dolphins. One accident from profit first companies located outside of the Commonwealth and we will lose decades in economic recovery.

Wind turbines are the sensible solution and we wouldn't even be discussing their merits it if it weren't for the money in politics from the well established oil conglomerates still pushing last century technologies. There may be money in it for them to gain and politicians willing to do their bidding for their campaign coffers, but there is more money in it for Virginia Beach to lose, a lot and it affects us all not just the questionable politician or some CFO's salary. For our children, our food, our livelihoods, and our health wind turbines and solar energy are not only beneficial, they are real solutions to the consistent and persistent byproduct of our old dirty energy sources. Comment to classify: Dear BOEM Officials:

Thank you for this opportunity to comment on the Environmental Assessment (EA) for the Virginia Offshore Wind Technology Project (VOWTAP). While I support Dominion's two test turbine project, such development must be done in a way that ensures robust protections for marine mammals and sea turtles, in particular for the North American right whale (NARW).

In order to support a Finding of No Significant Issues (FONSI), BOEM must amend the final EA to include the following measures:
prohibit pile-driving during the NARWs peak migratory season from Nov. 1 to April 30
during that time, place a uniform 10-knot speed limit restriction on all vessels of any length affiliated with the VOWTAP project
provide for a minimum of four qualified observers located at the pile driving site
require the developer to use the best commercially available technology to reduce noise associated with construction of the VOWTAP project

I applaud BOEM's efforts to bring clean renewable offshore wind power online as soon as possible. The crisis we face with climate change demands it. We in Virginia are especially vulnerable to its impacts with our Hampton Roads area being second only to New Orleans in its vulnerability to sea level rise.

From the VOWTAP project, critical information and "lessons learned" can be gleaned that can facilitate Dominion's timely build-out of its adjacent commercial lease area. We urge BOEM to work closely with Dominion and other project developers to facilitate build-out of the commercial lease area as soon as practicable, getting a substantial amount of wind power in operation no later than 2020.

Finally, offshore wind development can provide a valuable compliance tool in meeting Virginia's obligations under the EPA's Clean Power Plan - assuming it comes on line in a timely manner.

Thank you again for this opportunity to comment.

Sincerely,
[387 Virginia residents - see attached pdf]

Comment to classify: Comments on DG-5027 (RG 5.12 Rev. 1)
Regulatory Position C.1 covers the selection and use of locks to protect National Security Information, Restricted Data, and Formally Restricted Data and references 10 CFR 95.25(a).
10 CFR 95.25(a) states:
(a) Secret matter, while unattended or not in actual use, must be stored in--
(1) A safe, steel file cabinet, or safe-type steel file container that has an automatic unit locking mechanism. All such receptacles will be accorded supplemental protection during non-working hours; or
(2) Any steel file cabinet that has four sides and a top and bottom (all permanently attached by welding, rivets, or peened bolts so the contents cannot be removed without leaving visible evidence of entry) and is secured by a rigid metal lock bar and an approved key operated or combination padlock. The keepers of the rigid metal lock bar must be secured to the cabinet by welding, rivets, or bolts, so they cannot be removed and replaced without leaving evidence of the entry. The drawers of the container must be held securely so their contents cannot be removed without forcing open the drawer. This type of cabinet will be accorded supplemental protection during non-working hours.
The current regulation and the Draft Regulatory Guide contradicts what is written in the National Industrial Security Program Operators Manual (NISPOM), DoD 52200.22-M, dated February 28, 2006 Incorporating Change 1, March 28, 2013. The NISPOM only allowed the use of non-GSA security storage containers prior to October 1, 2012. After the effective date, only GSA approved security storage containers may be used to protect this type of information.
NISPOM Section 5-303 states:

SECRET Storage. SECRET material shall be stored in a GSA-approved security container, an approved vault, or closed area. Supplemental controls are required for storage in closed areas. The following additional storage methods may be used until October 1, 2012:
a. A safe, steel file cabinet, or safe-type steel file container that has an automatic unit locking mechanism. All such receptacles will be accorded supplemental protection during non-working hours.
b. Any steel file cabinet that has four sides and a top and bottom (all permanently attached by welding, rivets or peened bolts so the contents cannot be removed without leaving visible evidence of entry) and is secured by a rigid metal lock bar and an approved key operated or combination padlock. The keepers of the rigid metal lock bar shall be secured to the cabinet by welding, rivets, or bolts so they cannot be removed and replaced without leaving evidence of the entry. The drawers of the container shall be held securely so their contents cannot be removed without forcing open the drawer. Comment to classify: Docket ID NRC-2014-0276: FirstEnergy Nuclear Operating Company (FENOC) Comments on Draft Regulatory Guide DG-5027, General Use of Locks in Protection and Control of Facilities and Special Nuclear Materials, Classified Matter, and Safeguards Information

1. In response to 80 FR 53, FirstEnergy Nuclear Operating Company (FENOC) has reviewed the draft regulatory guide (RG), and appreciates the opportunity to provide the following comments.

The draft RG indicates that only the Federal Specification FF-L-2740 model X-09 lock is currently being produced. Industry information indicates a subsequent Model X-10 is now in production that should be evaluated for inclusion in this regulatory guide.

Starting on page 5 of the RG, with the reference number for Federal Specification FF-L-2740, reference numbers are incorrect. For example, Federal Specification FF-L-2740 is identified as reference 11, but Federal Specification FF-L-2740A is actually reference 12. Reference 11 is Lock Industry Standards and Training Council, The Professional Locksmith Dictionary, 2006.

2. Should you have any questions or comments, please contact:

H. Philip Rowe
FENOC Fleet Security Specialist
Office (330) 315-6901

or

Darin M. Benyak
FENOC Director, Fleet Security
Office (330) 315-6909

Comment to classify: Thank you for providing notice of the referenced project. The Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma is unaware of any documentation directly linking Indian Religious Sites to the proposed project location. There appear to be no objects of cultural significance or artifacts linked to our tribe located on or near the project location.

The Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma is unaware of items covered under NAGPRA (Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act) to be associated with the proposed project site. These items include: funerary or sacred objects; objects of cultural patrimony; or ancestral human remains.

The Peoria Tribe has no objection at this time to the proposed license renewal. If, however, at any time items are discovered which fall under the protection of NAGPRA, the Peoria Tribe requests immediate notification and consultation. In addition state, local and tribal authorities should be advised as to the findings and construction halted until consultation with all concerned parties has occurred.

Thank you,
Cynthia Stacy
Special Projects Manager/NAGPRA
Peoria Tribe of Indians of Oklahoma
118 S. Eight Tribes Trail
PO Box 1527
Miami, OK 74355-1527
P (918)540-2535 | F (918)540-2538

Comment to classify: DOCKET NUMBER NRC-2013-0178 Byron Nuclear Power Plant Relicensing

I oppose the license renewal for the Byron Plant because it is a not environmentally sound and is a serious threat to human health and safety.

I am a 72 year old male retiree, residing ca. 20 miles south-southwest of the facility. I have family members--including children--living 5-10 miles from the plant and I fear for their health and safety. Research reveals increased cancer risk for those living within 10 miles of nuclear power plants and other studies show that nuclear workers have a greater risk of cancer than the survivors of Hiroshima/Nagasaki bombings in WWII. Nuclear power plants emit radiation daily and more serious releases occur during refueling.

There is no safe level of radiation. The health consequences of exposure to continued low levels are worse than one high level exposure.

Exelon's competence in operating Byron is questionable, as indicated in "Toxic Management Erodes Safety at 'World's Safest' Nuclear Plant" by Dreux Richard (The Japan Times, March 11, 2013). The allegations in this article have not been adequately or publicly addressed by Exelon or the NRC in my estimation, and the suggestion by the NRC Public Relations staff that I dig through reams of documents to see if the situation was adequately dealt with leaves me cold. An associate of mine was a career employee at Byron who took early retirement out of frustration and disgust, stating, "Nuclear power is fine--if its done right." (And also indicates that most of the above mentioned ariticle is true).

I recommend tthat the NRC institute policies and procedures to assure that Exelon and other plant operators maintain management practices that do not intimidate employees who are trying to ensure safe operation of nuclear power plants, and to inform the public of violations of said policies and remediation of said violations. Toxic management does not assure safety for the health of the environment, the public, and staff.

The alternatives to the renewal of the Byron license are clear and viable: Wind, solar and other renewable energy sources are now environmentally and economically sound. It is time to let this Nuclear Neanderthal technology die a hopefully swift death.

Thank you.

Comment to classify: On behalf of UCS, I submitted FOIA/PA-2015-0082 seeking Final Safety Analysis Report records received after October 1, 2001, by the NRC from all nuclear plant owners, including the Byron licensee. By letter dated January 7, 2015, the NRC administratively closed my request. By email dated December 30, 2014, the NRC staff notified me that the estimated page count for the requested records was 448,000 just from Region IV. That email estimated approximately 4,000 pages per FSAR per reactor with multiple updates per reactor since October 1, 2001 -- accounting for the hundreds of thousands of pages per region.

By withholding this vast quantity of FSAR material from the public, the NRC is significantly impairing our ability to review and comment on licensing request such as this one for Byron. The FSARs describe the safety-related structures, systems, and components at the plant and further describe their role in preventing or mitigating design basis transients and accidents.

NRC regulation 10 CFR 50.59 requires licensees to screen proposed modifications and changes to plant operating procedures to see whether the proposed changes might reduce safety margins approved by the NRC in a significant way. If so, the changes cannot be made until after the NRC reviews and formally approves them. The 10 CFR 50.59 screenings and evaluations rely heavily on information in the FSARs. The FSARs are also extensively used by NRC's reviewers when evaluating licensee requests for licensing actions.

As stated above, by withholding hundreds of thousands of pages of FSARs from the public, the NRC is significantly impairing our ability to participating in licensing proceedings in a meaningful away. The licensees and the NRC staff rely heavily on the FSAR information while preparing and reviewing requests for licensing actions, but the NRC's withholding prevents the public from reviewing this information.

The hundreds of thousands of pages of vital information being withheld by the NRC staff is being done so improperly. Entire FSARs, such as the recent updates for Beaver Valley Unit 2 and Watts Bar Unit 2, were made publicly available by the NRC in their entirety. This demonstrates that FSARs do not contain classified, safeguards, or sensitive information that must be withheld from public disclosure.

The NRC should not approve this licensing request at Byron until after the agency makes all the FSAR information for Byron publicly available and gives the public sufficient time to review this information. Failing to do so transforms this licensing process into a mockery of justice. Comment to classify: I recommend that a level of prevailing severy level (high, medium or low) be added to the HPMS "Cracking %" reporting requirement to be used as one of the pavement condition rating threshold in the regulation. This will help better describe the severity of the cracking present in each HPMS reporting section ( 0.1 mile in lenght), therefore resulting in a more accurate assessment of the actual pavement condition in each HPMS reproting section. For example, a HPMS section may have less than 5% of cracking on the surface but the severity of that cracking may be high based on prevaling standards, while another HPMS section may have 20% cracking with low severity. For me the section with < 5% cracking may be consider poor based on the severity of its cracking instead of good based on the current criteria included in the proposed regulation. Comment to classify: Some comments on Pavement Condition Measures

International Roughness Index (IRI) has long been part of the HPMS but as a measure of roughness, it should not be the sole pavement performance measure.

In or around 1995 a pavement was rated as poor if the IRI was greater than 220 but this was for the non-interstate routes whereas the threshold for the interstate routes was set at 170. Reference past issues of Highway Statistics to find this metric. Now the proposal is to set the threshold at 170 outside of all urban areas that have less than one million population and then at 220 inside the urban areas that have more than one million population for the non-interstate NHS. A pavement with an IRI between 170 and 220 may be rough but it is not necessarily in need of rehabilitation or maintenance. A PCI rating may be a better indicator of that since it has to do with condition and not only roughness.

According to the statewide Local Streets and Roads needs assessment done in California, about 80-90% of the pavement ratings are done in PCI (Pavement Condition Index) or similar, which is pretty much all the cities and counties that reported to the needs assessment survey.

But how many agencies measure IRI? It is principally the state DOT that has to assume this responsibility.

The burden and time and cost of measuring the IRI on all of the NHS and the samples of minor arterial and collector streets seems to be a greater challenge than collecting PCI from the MPOs. PCI is almost always easier to obtain and less costly than IRI and PCI is standardized under the specification ASTM D 6433 (2007).

As for the HPMS connection, PSR is reported in the HPMS and PCI can be converted to PSR. This is not to say that it isnt as easy to create one more data item and report the PCI.

In 2014 dollars, California has to spend 3-4 million annually to collect the IRI. The faulting, rutting and cracking will be about another 1-2 million annually. Nationally, this could run $40-50 million every year to comply with the reporting for the IRI, faulting, rutting and cracking along with the person-hours of contract administration since most of this work is done under contract.

It may be worthwhile to reexamine the business case for using PCI as a pavement performance measure.

Comment to classify: After viewing both webinars and reviewing the Federal Register over the past couple of weeks, I am left with some questions:

1. Baseline Report - 490.107(b)(1)
- Will all pavement condition metrics (IRI, Rutting, Faulting, Cracking) be required on the Baseline Report?
- Will both Interstate and Non-Interstate NHS pavement data be required on the Baseline Report?
- Will pavement data from 2014, 2015, and 2016 collection seasons be allowed on the Baseline Report or is only 2016 data permitted?

2. Missing Data - 490.313(b)(4)(I)
- If we are unable to collect and report pavement data on a section of road because it is in the process of improvement, will it still default to a "Poor" rating?

3. Proposed Field Manual
- When will the proposed field that reflects these changes become available?
- Will the HPMS Field Manual continue to be re-released every year?

4. Cracking - 490.311(b)(2)
- The current HPMS Field Manual states that transverse cracks under 6 feet in length are not to be counted as part of the reported cracking length. Will smaller transverse cracks now be included in "the total area containing visible cracks"?
- The current HPMS Field Manual states that only fatigue cracking in the wheel paths are to be counted as part of the reported percent of fatigue cracking. Will fatigue cracking anywhere in the lane now be included in "the total area containing visible cracks"?
- The current HPMS reporting methods require transverse cracks to be reported in length and fatigue cracks be reported in area. The new Cracking Percent metric is calculated by "the percent of the total area containing visible cracks", how is this calculated since a transverse cracking linear measurement has no area?

5. Faulting - 490.311(b)(4)(iii)
- Will faulting be an average of all pavement joints in a section with or without measurable faulting heights, or will it be an average of only the joints with faulting measurements greater than zero?

6. Bridges - 490.313(f)(1)
- Are State DOTs responsible for removing sections from the report that have bridges in them?
- If State DOTs are required to remove bridge sections from the report, how will these sections not be automatically graded as "Poor" because it is considered missing data?
- Will sections that contain bridge approaches also be removed?

7. Comment to classify: My recommendation is to incorporate a clause into this rule that promotes the support of small businesses across the nation, within each state and county, so as to encourage the economic growth within each region that will already be given a boost if this rule is passed due to the increase in demand for civil contractors as well as the new positions the DOT will be required to hire in support of the inspection and construction accounting associated with each new project. I believe it is imperative that this new rule doesnt end up catering to the Oligopoly or even Monopoly that the exists with the big general contractors such as Las Vegas Asphalt Paving in Las Vegas, NV who currently consumes the majority of asphalt paving in Clark County. Furthermore, some level of marketing for the availability of this type of work to current small business general contractors should be included for this feat.
I fully support this new proposed rule as it takes a major step in the right direction to correcting the overload of renovations and new roads and bridges that this growing nation requires. I support the initiative to enable the DOT as the enforcer and authority to issue fines to those regions who are in violation of this new rule. I also support the given target time periods for renovations as reasonable. The 2-4 year period is more than sufficient, as long as the language is explicit in that reasonable time be allotted for weather delays or other uncontrollable circumstances so that no fines be levied for such delays. I do feel that the cost benefits might be a bit understated. Certainly places that are experiencing high traffic volumes that are given funding for the widening of the roads or where new bridges provide access quicker to areas will benefit the local economies as well the social mentality from lessening their daily commute. Not to mention the superordinate goal of keeping cars on the road less to bring down CO2 emissions.

Comment to classify: One of the most critical problems in asphalt pavement construction today is achieving a long lasting longitudinal joint. It is costing agencies billions worldwide in premature repair of the joint. This problem has been recognized for a couple of decades, and discussed at many asphalt pavement seminars, the subject of much research, with little or no progress in many jurisdictions.

The problem stems from a lack of density on the edge of the first paved lane, as the compactor has nothing to compact against. This results in a push sideways at the edge, and a lack of compacted density on the outer 3-6 inches, typically 4-6 per cent less than the density of the mat. This lack of density, according to considerable research, can translate into a reduction of 20-35% in the life of a pavement, because a low density means more water penetration, more freeze thaw action, more moisture deterioration of the bitumen/aggregate bond. Further, it means a lower strength that is not capable of withstanding todays heavy traffic loads, and once the crack occurs, a concentration of load on each side of the crack as the wheel passes over, to further stress the joint area.

Historically, paving contractors were able to produce a better joint by limiting the length of a paved lane, moving back and matching the joint while reasonably hot. With traffic control making short paved lanes impractical, plus the advent of multi lane highways, moving back to match the warm joint has been all but eliminated on highways. Hence, a lack of density and water impermeability, and early deterioration of the joint.
In a 2012 Asphalt Institute/Federal Highways Report: Best Practices for Constructing and Specifying HMA Longitudinal Joint, a 2002 Kentucky Transportation Center quote is provided :" Many pavements have been, or are in the process of being, resurfaced as a direct or indirect result of longitudinal joint deteriorations. This statement is relevant today.

The report also cites an FHWA Division Office survey: half the respondents were not satisfied with the overall performance of longitudinal joints in their states. Thirty-five (35) states said they had some sort of longitudinal joint specification or special provision, but only half of those states (17) reported that they had a minimum density requirement at the joint. "The minimum density required was as low as 89% leaving the pavement with a 35% reduction in life.

Some states have actually specified that any quality control cores must be taken certain distances from the joint since it would not represent mat densities, and have no requirement to test the joint.

The AI/FHWA study just covered the United States. The same problem exists in Canada, and worldwide.

With the serious lack of funding to continue maintaining our infrastructure, it becomes critical that this longitudinal joint construction problem be eliminated, so our roads can last longer.

Comment to classify: One aspect of the pavement performance measures that should be considered is the exposure and risk factors associated with the rated conditions. That is, the specified performance conditions should be the minimum allowable condition at any time on the Interstate System. For example, after spring thaws or periods of significant inclement weather which has recently happened over a large extent of the US, potholes can become frequent and can have a dramatic impact on safety based on their severity and the time of exposure to traffic.

The rationale described here is that good roads do not pothole, but poorer roads can receive good ratings if temporary repairs are made just prior to the annual evaluations. The "actual" good roads will not incur the same exposure risk as will the "poorer" roads which rated good. The current procedures appear to be based on annual assessments that only characterize the roadway at that moment in time and hence cannot account for the exposure risk. This does not ensure the safety of the interstate system.

In addition to establishing a minimum condition goal, it might also be useful to look at other strategies to discriminate between a good road and a poorer road that rates good. Although strategies like evaluating areas of localized roughness in profile evaluations could help delineate this issue, it would be labor intensive. Perhaps using traffic as probe vehicles with a call in number for unacceptable road conditions could perform as a check on the current system and could be used as a means to require supplemental evaluations or actually to trump the annual evaluations and to change the rating. There could also be another category of performance measure which would require repair of "extreme conditions" to ensure safety and minimize exposure.

During the several years that these performance standards will be integrated into working practice, in-vehicle communications with the infrastructure are also being developed by the auto manufacturers and in the not to distant future traffic streams can be used to characterize the interstate system for the occurrences of unacceptable roadway conditions. Comment to classify: The FHWA determination that this rule making would not affect a taking of private property ( EO 12630 Taking of Private Property ) is not considering that repaving and certain pavement maintenance activities requires bringing facilities in conformance with the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 (ADA). Often ROW is required for these upgrades, and the cost of ADA facility upgrades can often exceed the costs of the repaving activities alone. Section 1B of EO 12630 requires "Executive departments and agencies should review their actions carefully to prevent unnecessary takings and should account in decision-making for those takings that are necessitated by statutory mandate". The EO 12630 preamble states "in order to ensure that government actions are undertaken on a well-reasoned basis with due regard for fiscal accountability, for the financial impact of the obligations imposed on the Federal government". I am concerned that ADA ROW & Facility Costs that are part of the asset maintenance costs, are omitted from the assessment and actual financial and hourly burdens (Paperwork Reduction Act) for implementing the rulemaking, and will be actually much larger than the rulemaking predicts. These increased costs may invoke violation of the Unfunded Mandates Reform
Act of 1995 despite FHWA declaring the rulemaking would not.

I suspect "lack of funding" will be cited as why pavement and bridge assets were allowed to decline. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 states "in the absence of full consideration by Congress, of Federal mandates on State, local, and tribal
governments without adequate funding, in a manner that may displace other essential governmental priorities; and to ensure that the Federal Government pays the costs incurred by those governments in complying". In the rulemaking, FHWA speaks of imposing financial penalties for non-compliance. If an asset owner cannot fiscally meet physical requirements of the rulemaking, how does this not invoke the situation that Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 addresses?

ADA was not mentioned in this rulemaking, and I believe needs to be.

Comment to classify: A major issue with the pavement performance measure of IRI has been difficulty of measuring it with typical technology at speeds of 35 mph or less and unders top and start conditions.

The University of California Pavement Research Center has recently been evaluating a new Smart Car mounted profiler developed by SSI that is capable of measuring IRI at slow speeds and it appears that filters can added that will produce clean profiles and IRI values under stop and start conditions.

This advance in technology, which is likely under development by other technology providers, will allow local government to have IRI measured on their routes.

Why does IRI matter for local government? Roughness affects rider comfort, but more importantly it affects vehicle fuel economy, particularly for heavy trucks moving at slow speeds according to recently -recalibrated HDM4 models reported in NCHRP Report 720 (work done by Michigan State University). Comment to classify: The American Association of Immunologists (AAI), the largest professional association of immunologists in the world, representing more than 7,600 basic and clinical immunologists, appreciates this opportunity to submit comments to the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) Request for Information (RFI): Identifying and Reducing Regulatory Burden. AAI is pleased that the USDA has initiated this effort, since regulatory burden is a significant barrier to the productivity and efficiency of the nations scientific researchers.

In their research, AAI members use and depend on animals and therefore have a deep interest in all matters governing their care and use. AAI appreciates that the USDA is seeking ways to ensure the humane care and use of animals without unnecessarily or inadvertently reducing scientific research capacity or disrupting, impeding, or burdening the research scientists who spend their careers in search of answers and cures.

AAI members are funded by a wide range of federal agencies, including the National Institutes of Health (NIH); the Department of Defense (DOD); the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA); the USDA; the Department of Energy (DOE); and the National Science Foundation (NSF). Many members receive grants from multiple agencies over the course of their careers. As a result, AAI hopes that issues identified and addressed by USDA will spur action by, and coordination among, the many federal science agencies to reduce investigators regulatory burdens.

In addition to our comments below, AAI urges the USDA to consider carefully the thoughtful and comprehensive comments submitted by the Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology (FASEB), of which AAI is a founding member, and the American Physiological Society (APS). Both groups have offered well-reasoned suggestions for the reduction of regulatory burden.

Exempt some biomedical procedures performed on agricultural animals from compliance with USDA regulations
The guidelines contained in Licensing and Registration Under the Animal Welfare Act (AWA), Guidelines for Dealers, Exhibitors, Transporters, and Researchers, which were issued by the USDAs Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), specify that, [i]nstitutions using any regulated live animals for research, testing, teaching, or experimentation must register with the USDA as research facilities. Under the guidelines, however, Agricultural Research Institutions are exempt. These institutions include those that, perform work involving food, fiber, or agriculture and that use horses and domestic farm animals, including rabbits as long as they are not performing nonagricultural biomedical research. Comment to classify: Comment: Submitted on behalf of the Animals in Research Committee (12 members), of the College on Problems on Drug Dependence (2,300 members)

Author: Dr. Michael Gatch, Committee Member

Submitted by: Dr. Marilyn Carroll Santi, Committee Chair

There is no need for additional clarification of terms in the AWA concerning pain, distress, and the search for better alternatives, largely because there is already a substantial body of literature available to investigators, IACUC members, veterinary staff, and the general public. Amendment to the AWA regulations would not provide additional useful information, may conflict with the consensus that exists between the regulatory groups and scientific organizations, and would add additional regulatory burden without improving quality of care. We will address each of these two issues separately.
1) There already exists adequate information available on interpretation of pain and distress in animals. In fact, investigator concerns about animal pain and distress has generated a large body of information and opinion. The USDA has a classification of pain and distress1, there have been periodic updates in USDA regulations, including a recent release2, there are various documents written by major research organizations3 and by the Office of Laboratory Animal Welfare (OLAW)4. There are also reviews of concerns about pain and distress in experimentation in the biomedical literature (1 review in 20155), and ongoing discussion in laboratory animal care journals6,7.
Resources:
1. USDA Classification
Classification B: Animals being bred, conditioned, or held for use in teaching, testing, experiments, research, or surgery, but not yet used for such purposes.
Classification C: Animals upon which testing, research, experiments, or tests will be conducted involving no pain, distress, or use of pain-relieving drugs.
Classification D: Animals upon which experiments, teaching, research, tumor bearing experiments, surgery, or tests will be conducted which have the potential to cause pain or distress to the animals and for which appropriate anesthetic, analgesic, or tranquilizing drugs will be used to prevent this pain and distress.
Classification E: Animals upon which teaching, experiments, research, surgery, or tests will be conducted involving accompanying pain or distress to the animals and for which the use of appropriate anesthetic, analgesic, or tranquilizing drugs will adversely

2. Policies Animal Care Resource Guide
Painful Procedures Issue Date: March 25, 2011
Subject: Painful and Distressful Procedures Policy #11
References: AWA Section 2143
9 CFR, Part 2, Sections 2.31(d)(1)(i,ii,iv), 2.31(e)(4), 2.33(b)(4), 2.36(b)(5,6,7)

3. Recognition and Alleviation of Pain in Laboratory Animals (2009). Institute for Laboratory Animal Research, National Academy of Sciences.

4. Comment to classify: These comments are submitted on behalf of the American Physiological Society.

Which regulations, reporting requirements, or regulatory submission or application processes are unnecessarily complicated or could be streamlined to achieve regulatory objectives in ways that are more efficient?

Alternatives search requirement: As currently applied, the alternatives search requirement is an inefficient and burdensome approach to Animal Welfare Act 2143(a)(3)(B). This section mandates that the Principal Investigator considers alternatives to any procedure likely to produce pain or distress in an experimental animal. The regulatory interpretation of this section should be modified. Animal Care Policy #12 recommends a database search as the most effective and efficient method for demonstrating compliance with the requirement to consider alternatives to painful and/or distressful procedures. It further states that researchers should submit the names of the databases searched; the dates of searches; the time periods covered by the searches; and key words and specific strategies used in such searches. This requires significant effort on the part of the investigator while providing little insight into the investigators actual consideration of alternatives strategies, which are defined by Russell and Burch1 as efforts to reduce, refine, or replace potentially painful procedures.

We recommend that APHIS instead require a brief written narrative justifying the selection of the animal model including how reduction, refinement and/or replacement were incorporated into the consideration of animal numbers. Such a narrative gives the review body (IACUC) much more insight into the consideration of alternatives, satisfies the regulatory objectives of the Animal Welfare Act, and reduces burden for researchers.

W.M.S. Russell and R.L. Burch. The Principles of Humane Experimental Technique. Accessed at http://altweb.jhsph.edu/pubs/books/humane_exp/het-toc

Expired medical materials: When cited, the presence of expired medical materials should be classified as an IACUC issue. AWA 2143 (a)(3)(A), which addresses adequate veterinary care, authorizes the USDA to issue standards for animal care, treatment, and practices in experimental procedures to ensure that animal pain and distress are minimized, including adequate veterinary care with the appropriate use of anesthetic, analgesic, tranquilizing drugs, or euthanasia. The specific guidance of APHIS Policy #3 states that the use of expired medical materials such as drugs, fluids, sutures, anesthetics, sedatives, or analgesics on regulated animals during a survival procedure is considered inadequate veterinarian care. Therefore, facilities should either dispose of all such materials or segregate them in an appropriately labeled, physically separate location from non-expired medical materials. Comment to classify: Public Comments on the Proposed Collection of Information on the Development of Nutrition Education Messages and Products for the General Public
October 7, 2015

On behalf of The Dannon Company, we thank you for the opportunity to submit comments regarding proposed information collection for development of nutrition education messages and products for the general public. As a leading yogurt manufacturer for more than 70 years, we are committed to bringing health through food to as many people as possible. In addition, we recognize and appreciate the important work of the USDA CNPP in developing nutrition education messages and resources that support the Dietary Guidelines for Americans.

Collection of consumer feedback in development of nutrition education messaging is a critical step toward ensuring that the messages developed are practical, actionable, simple and specific, and may hopefully help result in Americans shifting to healthier dietary habits including the consumption of more nutrient dense foods. Research should include efforts to determine message actionability that motivates behavior change in order to have the greatest practical utility both at the individual level as well as from a broader public health population perspective. We agree that the proposed consumer research should address both general population and special population groups as mentioned in the federal register notice, with the following thoughts for additional consideration.

While general population insights and messages are needed, specific target groups as mentioned in the Federal Register (including low-income consumers, children, older Americans, educators and students) are important audiences. We also believe that the inclusion of ethnic populations as food choices and food behaviors vary greatly among ethnic cultures would provide additional valuable insights. As highlighted by the 2015 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee, the disparities in obesity and chronic disease rates exist not only for the low income population but are also prevalent for certain ethnic and racial groups. So it is critical messages and tools developed for those populations be efficient in creating behavior change and help close health disparity gaps as well.

The ages and life stages between childhood and older adult years, namely the young adult, young and growing families and middle-age years, are also important audience segments that we believe would be beneficial to include in the evaluation. These life stages are critically important groups to understand when it comes to developing nutrition education messages that are relevant, workable and that can drive scale among consumers. In addition to ethnicity/culture and life stage, household size significantly impacts food preparation behaviors. Accounting for these factors would also enhance the insights gleaned from the study.

Comment to classify: I am honored to submit this comment on behalf of [fourteen] nationally-recognized nutrition researchers, scientists and other public health professionals, in support of the Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion's plans to undertake consumer research to test nutrition education messages and products for the general public. We further ask that such research include testing of a symbol for water on MyPlate. Last year we urged the Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee to recommend strong language in the 2015 Dietary Guidelines for Americans (DGAs) regarding the benefits of water consumption as a beverage of choice, and they did so. Advice in the DGAs on drinking water should be translated out to the general public with a water symbol on MyPlate.

We all know that the American public consumes sugar-sweetened beverages (SSBs) in excess and that calories and added sugars from SSBs are a major contributor to the national epidemic of diabetes and overweight and obesity. And we know that water should be promoted as a beverage of choice and as the best non-caloric substitute for SSBs. The attached letter highlights recent evidence that confirms the advisability of supporting the language in the Guidelines with a water symbol on MyPlate, the translation of the Guidelines most often seen by children and their families.

Comment to classify: Thank you for proposing that FBOs that receive federal funding must provide written notice to beneficiaries of their rights, and must refer beneficiaries who object to the FBO's religious character to a secular provider. Comment to classify: Erosion of the bill of rights and changing of laws to benefit the few has been going on for decades. Please return us to the original intent of the first amendment. We must include the non-discrimination of workers in explicitly religious entities AND make sure evidence (symbols, signs, proselytizing to clients in any way) of their real purpose is excluded from the site of tax sponsored services, direct or indirect.

In fact, we could make it simple and remove ALL tax payer subsidies from religious organizations. The first amendment makes it clear there should be no support. The real estate tax exemption alone is over the top support as it is. And don't get me started about the politics from the pulpit that is illegal and rampant. I appreciate the time you take to consider things that affect so many people.

Comment to classify: Thank you for proposing that FBOs that receive federal funding must provide written notice to beneficiaries of their rights, and must refer beneficiaries who object to the FBO's religious character to a secular provider. I really don't want my tax money going to promote a religion I don't believe in.

I find it very disturbing that these federal funded programs are allowed to discriminate with who they hire and that they can openly display religious symbols when tax dollars are funding their services.

Ensuring people are free to believe whatever religion they want is one of the fundamental and core values of America. And ensuring that the christian majority in our country doesn't trample on the freedom of others is an important protection to maintain. Please make sure that these types of organizations are not able to receive indirect funding from tax payers either, through the use of voucher programs for example. We need to protect future generations from the bigotry and intolerance that majority religions often promote. Dear Ms. Deluhery:
The Georgia Food Bank Association is comprised of 8 Feeding America Food Banks who distributed more than 121 million pounds of food through a statewide network of 2,500 partner agencies and pantries in Georgia last year. 156,500 clients receive emergency food assistance from our network every WEEK. We are a member of the Feeding America network of 200 food banks and 58,000 local agencies. We appreciate the opportunity to comment on this important rulemaking. While most of the food we provide comes from private donations, we are very grateful for the food and financial support we receive from USDA. USDA foods are extremely nutritious and highly sought after by clients, agencies and food banks alike.
Many of the provisions in the proposed rulemaking are a reiteration of existing policy, such as the importance of separating any religious activities from the provision of federal resources, and the requirement that that our beneficiaries not be required to participate in any religious activities as a condition of receiving federal assistance. These types of requirements are well understood by the food bank and the agencies we support and are a point of emphasis in frequent training sessions.
Nationally, our network relies heavily on volunteers and on Faith Based organizations. Of the 54,000 agencies supplied by food banks, 51% are staffed only by volunteers, and 62% are Faith-Based organizations. In Georgia, that figure is higher: 74% of our partner agencies are faith based with more than 60% run by volunteers. In rural areas of our state, the faith based pantries are the only organizations working in food assistance. Thus it is critically important that we not over-burden our volunteers, nor discourage Faith-Based organizations from continuing support hungry families and individuals.
The new requirements regarding referrals of beneficiaries to other potential providers are an area of significant concern to us and to most food banks. Our comments in this regard fall into two categories. First, we believe that our work in providing meals and food for home consumption meets the definition of USDA indirect assistance. Our rationale is provided in the following paragraph. Second, should USDA choose to categorize this work as USDA direct assistance we would ask that several provisions be clarified or made more explicit.
Both the proposed rule and the Supreme Court decision cited in the preamble use as the principle distinction between direct and indirect federal assistance whether the beneficiary of the service has the ability to choose the provider of such services.
