Comment to classify: Thank you for proposing that FBOs that receive federal funding must provide written notice to beneficiaries of their rights, and must refer beneficiaries who object to the FBO's religious character to a secular provider. I also urge you to require that these reforms be applied to FBOs that receive federal funding through a voucher program or other "indirect" means. Federal funds should never be used to promote religion.

While the proposed rules help to prevent FBOs from using taxpayer dollars to promote religion, they do not go far enough. As a U.S. taxpayer and citizen, I am strongly opposed to allowing FBOs to discriminate in their hiring, and to display religious symbols where federally funded services are offered.

Thomas G Johnson

Comment to classify: If an agency accepts taxpayer money, they must hire their employees based on merit, not on the applicant's belief or non-belief in the "faith" of the organization. I have stopped donating to the Salvation Army, and any other religious charity, because of this violation of the First Amendment.
I disagree that the charity may have religious icons and symbols in the same space where they provide services--this constitutes government endorsement of that religion, and would make an adherent of a different religion feel unwelcome or at worst intimidated--no crucifixes, no Torahs, no Korans.
All the donations I used to make to "faith-based" charities are now going to Planned Parenthood, where people of every, any, or no religion, are made to feel welcome. Comment to classify: Hello, and thank you for reading my letter.

Thank you for proposing that FBOs that receive federal funding must provide written notice to beneficiaries of their rights, and must refer beneficiaries who object to the FBO's religious character to a secular provider. The bait and switch has to stop, beneficiaries should never be subjected to overt or indirect religious proseletyzing simply to receive what is lawfully theirs.

I also am urging you to require that these reforms be applied to FBOs that receive federal funding through a voucher program or other "indirect" means. Federal funds should never be used to promote religion. As a taxpayer, I am sick and tired of supporting this or that variation of the invisible Sky Daddy.

While the proposed rules help to prevent FBOs from using taxpayer dollars to promote religion, they do not go far enough. As a U.S. taxpayer and citizen, I am STRONGLY OPPOSED to allowing FBOs to discriminate in their hiring, and to display religious symbols where federally funded services are offered.

Thanks
Jay Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Jay Mumford --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify: I strongly support the complete separation of government from religion and encourage your agency to oppose government support of, or to adopt strengthened accountability provisions concerning, "faith-based organizations (FBOs)". Specifically, FBOs receiving federal assistance must be prohibited from the display of "religious articles, texts, art, or symbols" in the spaces where they deliver federally funded services and must be treated like all other service providers or employers under federal law provisions and never discriminate in their hiring, or provision of services on the basis of bases of race, color, national origin, age, disability, sex, gender identity, religion, reprisal, and where applicable, political beliefs, marital status, familial or parental status, or sexual orientation.
Sincerely,
Mark Keiserman

Comment to classify: To whom it may concern,

Thank you for proposing that FBOs that receive federal funding must provide written notice to beneficiaries of their rights, and must refer beneficiaries who object to the FBO's religious character to a secular provider. I also urge you to require that these reforms be applied to FBOs that receive federal funding through a voucher program or other "indirect" means. Federal funds should never be used to promote religion.

While the proposed rules help to prevent FBOs from using taxpayer dollars to promote religion, they do not go far enough. As a U.S. taxpayer and citizen, I am strongly opposed to allowing FBOs to discriminate in their hiring, and to display religious symbols where federally funded services are offered.

Thank you for your time,

Comment to classify: I object to the glaring omission of any prohibition against FBOs discriminating in their hiring on the basis of religion. By "blessing" such a rule, the Obama Administration is approving, for instance, discrimination in the use of federal funds against LGBTQ applicants, or against an unmarried pregnant woman, or against an applicant who is an atheist or the "wrong religion." If an FBO accepts federal funds, it should have to play by federal rules. If, as a service provider or as an employer, an FBO is unwilling to open its doors to nonadherentsincluding religious minorities and the 23% of adult Americans who are nonreligiousthat FBO should not be offered public funds.
I also oppose the proposed rule allowing FBOs to display "religious articles, texts, art, or symbols" in the spaces where they deliver federally funded services. Beneficiaries of federally funded services will reasonably understand the government to endorse any religious messages or symbols in the area where the services are delivered. Just as a government entity cannot place religious iconography or messages on its walls, FBOs should be required to remove these symbols at the time and location they provide federally funded services. Beneficiaries in need should not be subjected to religious messages that conflict with their own beliefs in order to receive federally funded services. Comment to classify: In regard to rule changes implementing Executive Order 13559 regulation of faith-based organizations (FBOs), I see only a violation of the establishment clause. This is a Presidents personal belief system injected into secular government to provide subsidy to FBOs, and my taxes go to promoting religion. FBO provided aid, subsidized by the government, is simply another diversion of government funds to religion.

FBOs administrated by government agencies have no real and verifiable use of funds or activitiesa religious privilege and a blind-eye approach are unacceptable. Is an FBO required to provide assistance not in agreement with their religious beliefs, especially were the FBO the only reasonably available provider? The same as a County Clerk refusing to perform her secular job requirements, FBOs are restricted in what they provide in aid to others by their faith. FBOs therefore will not treat all equally under the lawconsider vociferous conservative Christian beliefs against LGBT and womens rights. Such beliefsunsubstantiated as they areare inherent to the aid they provide. Their beliefs cannot be government subsidized.

The very genesis of religion is to promote religious beliefsunsubstantiated beliefs. FBO motivated aid is a sectarian statement; in effect telling recipients that you are receiving this aid because of our god(s) or religious beliefs. This is proselytizing, and NO rule made by our government agencies funding FBO aid negates that. Why should I be forced to fund growth of FBO motivated aid?

Please cease funding sectarian religious charitable bents with my taxes. FBO regulation is undermining the governments secular obligation to help all citizens without regard to religion. Whereas, religious individuals can work for and support secularly administered government aid programsunless were it because of their sincerely held religious beliefscharity doled out by religious organizations, funded by everyones tax dollars, is endorsement of religion. Stop entangling religion with our governments aid programs.

Comment to classify: I believe that the proposal to expand the membership of the U.S. Highland Blueberry Council (Council) from 16 current members to 20 members would be beneficial to the Council to accept this increase in membership.
The U.S. Highbush Blueberry Council administers the Blueberry Promotion, Research and Information Order with oversight by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA). As the ultimate goal of the Council is to increase demand for highbush blueberries, the funding to attain this goal is by collection of assessments from domestic producers and importers. The stated reason for the increase of council membership is to help guarantee that the composition of the Council reflects the geographical distribution of domestic blueberry production and imports into the United States. Additional benefits of this proposed regulation are that the Councils nominations procedures would be further clarified, the number of members which are needed for a quorum would be increased, and eligibility requirements should be added for the public member on the council.
I believe this proposed increase in membership will better insure an increased representation amongst the varying geographical interests of the varying highland blueberry producers. Currently the Council is largely represented by the top six blueberry producing states, each of which contribute a producer member and an alternate member. These top six states are Michigan, Oregon, Washington, Georgia, New Jersey and California. This proposal will add North Carolina and Florida to the Council. I think the addition of these two states will provide for a better geographic representation on the council by adding the east coast and south east of the United States. It would appear that currently the west coast and the northern states are represented more heavily on the Council. Given the fact that the expenditure of tax dollars is impacted, by virtue of the USDA, it would seem that a greater representation of highland blueberry producers will be ensured by the adoption of this proposal.
Along with the greater diversity of the Council that this proposal will provided to those associated with the highland blueberry industry, this proposal also aims to add a public member to the Council. The proposal has stated that the public member not be a blueberry producer, handler, importer, exporter or have a financial interest in the production, marketing, sales or distribution of blueberries. I believe that the addition of this public member will be advantageous for the tax paying public due to their non-partisan opinion. The diversity component that this position on the Council will add will be advantageous to the Council and help it attain its goals.
Although I would support his proposal in its entirety if necessary, I would like to see a portion of it changed. The proposal addresses the issue of past due assessments which are payable to the Council for its funding. Comment to classify: I am writing on behalf of Domtar Corporation, a major North American paper manufacturer with facilities spread throughout the United States and Canada.

As one of North America's largest volume producers of printing and writing papers, Domtar is a long-time and committed supporter of the Paper and Packaging Board. Domtar's President and Chief Executive Officer, John D. Williams, is currently serving as the first chairman of that Board. On behalf of my nearly 9,500 colleagues, I am pleased with the early work the Paper and Packaging Board has produced. We look forward to the Board's continued work.

Understandably, the Board depends on assessments to complete its work, including assessments from certain foreign producers who import paper and packaging into the United States. Foreign and domestic producers alike benefit from the important work of the Board as we help to sustain and grow markets for paper and paper products. The Board needs to plan its work functions around predictable cash flow and if an assessment is late, the work of the Board can be disrupted.

Domtar supports the proposed late fee as outlined in the 2015-20437 Federal Register notice.

Sincerely,

Thomas S. Howard
Vice President, Government Relations

Comment to classify: The proposed revision highlighted under the USDA's Agriculture Marketing Service pertains to the removal of said word, "Unclassified" for means of establishing a standard due to the inaccurate grading representation for such items covered under the Department of Agriculture's guidelines. Furthermore, the components of this revision offer an interpretation of the acceptable grading standards for the categories of Fresh Produce, Produce Processing, and Nut and Specialty Crop Processing. In context, the accuracy of the standards is essentially the benchmark for acquisition. Many wholesalers, suppliers, growers, and consumers depend on the U.S. Standards for Grades, when determining the quality, consistency, and quantity. I happen to agree with the proposed revision of the standards. If the Department of Agriculture chose to vacate the proposed rule, the term "Unclassified" would cover items that have no former category, for reasons of obscurity. The proposed action initiates a focus on arguing that these items that are not commonalities, need to be further defined to be placed into a proposed category.

According to the Agricultural Marketing Service, grading standards are key indicators for industries to supply uniform information to suppliers, growers, and consumers on the size, quality, and condition of such items in the marketplace. Furthermore, it is the responsibility of the Agricultural Marketing Service to facilitate the process of acquiring these commodities through providing accurate, and informative grading standards that highlight the components aforementioned. Informing and providing accurate grading scales provides the everyday consumer with the necessary knowledge to make informed decisions. Same principle applies to the suppliers that have available measurements to determine the perishability and inconsistency of the commodities. Many supermarket chains and specialty shops rely on the grading standards for purchasing vast quantities.

If the Department of Agriculture chose to not execute the eradication of "Unclassified" from the grading standards, both consumers and market chains would not be able to discern what items are classified under this vague generalization. It is the sole responsibility of the Department of Agriculture to determine whether the removal of the "Unclassified" category would essentially be beneficial for the purpose of formalizing rules that adhere to specifying standards, or if this revision would essentially backfire, causing possible backlash from corporations that use the "Unclassified" Grading Standard to categorize a variety of their products. Comment to classify: Dear Sir or Madam,

As large grocery stores, restaurants, and other large quantity buyers purchase bulk produce it is crucial they know the quality of the food they are purchasing. Through the 46 proposed changes to the US Standards for Grades, an attempt to remove "unclassified" as a possible option has both positive and negative possible repercussions. If this regulation is passed. all food will be labeled. This will allow producers to grasp the quality of the food they are purchasing.

By knowing the quality of the food, these consumers will be informed buyers, able to make informed decisions. However, in the current situation food goes through rigorous investigation by multiple trained officials to determine the quality of the produce. In these cases the official denotes a grade to eat item. When an item does not fit any of the grades, it is determined to be "unclassified". "Unclassified" does not mean the produce is bad, it just means the produce does not fit any of the preset standards.

For example, at this time, raspberries are classified as U.S No. 1, US No. 2, or "unclassified". U.S No. 1 means the raspberries are "well developed and not soft, overripe, or broken; which are free from cores, sunscald, mold, and decay". US No. 2 means "fail to meet the requirements of the U.S. No. 1 grade but which do not contain more than 10 percent, by volume, of berries in any lot which are seriously damaged by any cause, including therein not more than 2 percent for berries which are affected by mold or decay". "Unclassified" raspberries do not fit either of the above categories.

By removing the "unclassified" section from raspberries, the USDA would have to determine every major variant of raspberry produce that could be of interest to the buyer. How would a raspberry batch be classified if many of the berries were overripe but none of them contained mold? How would a raspberry batch be classified if the berries were not well developed? The USDA would need to determine these difference for each of the 46 fruits, vegetables, and nuts that are under review for this policy.

I believe if this policy were to pass, the USDA would have to spend an enormous amount to time creating categories that apply to every piece of produce that is currently being labeled "unclassified". In addition, once these new categories are made, produce could be placed in categories not because they belong there, but because there is no where else to put them. By trying to properly label these 46 foods, the USDA could end up mislabeling them. Removing "unclassified" as an option could cause more harm than good. I think this proposal has good intention but would not be easily executed. For this reason I recommend that "unclassified" stays as an option.

Thank you for taking the time to consider my opinion. Comment to classify:
I do not support the proposed 20% market restriction for crop year 2015/16.  Normally I would be 100% supportive of this action but the proposal either ignores or is unaware of the new information regarding importation of significant amount of European/Turkey sourced concentrate.  It appears that over  200 million pounds of equivalent fruit is being imported.  This changes the market dynamic so significantly that a new plan needs to be created to regain market share from these imports.  By restricting the production tonnage we are actually subsidizing the imports by affording the importers higher prices.  The USA growers end up paying for the storage fees and driving grower prices down.  This is very short sited and again is not in the best interest of the growers.

Comment to classify: Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants. Comment to classify:
I rely on organic foods (and medicines) to keep me healthy. Without it, I would NOT be able to maintain a healthy body, mind, and spirit. Every time the government (and/or private companies) increases the amount of pesticides and toxic chemicals allowed in items such as Round-up, we as a species are inviting catastrophe. These chemicals wind up in our drinking water and our farms and gardens. Then they wind up in our food - and in our bodies. How many lethal cases of cancer or other disease does it take for you to understand the gravity of your laws and decisions? Do you truly NOT understand the connection between toxic chemicals allowed in poultry feed and the (now) ineffective antibiotics? How many children need to be hospitalized for ailments that are now life-threatening due to the mis-management and mis-use of these chemicals? How many thousands of bees must die before you understand how desperately WE RELY ON THEM for so much of our food???? PLEASE remove the chemicals, do NOT allow synthetic or otherwise non-organic substances to be allowed in what gets labelled "Organic"! MY HEALTH depends on KNOWING what I ingest!!!!!!

Comment to classify:
The problem of growing enough food for an over-populated planet of human beings is quite complex.  To introduce organic and sustainable farming on a worldwide basis is going to produce resistance from the usual business as usual.  Yet, business as usual is poisoning numerous species and the food produced as well.  Unfortunately, Monsanto and a number of other corporate selfish interests have no altruistic motivations or sensitivity to the repercussions of their pesticides and fertilizers.  And they are quite dictatorial in their demands upon the small and large farmer to do it their way or be scrutinized and put on 'a defiance list' of non cooperation.  This is absurd and must stop.-Robbin Zoupas

Comment to classify: Synthetic Methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date.

Nonorganic Agricultural Ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

Comment to classify: Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

Comment to classify: I am not a scientist, nor a farmer, but I do know that I choose to eat organic foods because I believe consuming chemicals from non-organic foods over time, is really bad for my health. Mother Nature created a healthy environment for us to use to grow food and while making improvements to her original plan is a great idea, I believe that using chemicals and pesticides to grow food is extremely dangerous both to our health, and the health of the planet. Chemicals were never on our Mother's agenda.

The NOSB was created to ensure that the organic label means what it says, that the food we are consuming is 100% organic. Unfortunately, the NOSB is continuing to allow the organic label to be watered down, little by little and the organic community is hoping that you will go back to your roots and remove ingredients that have no business being used on organic crops.

Therefore, I urge you to incorporate the following recommendations put forth by people advocating for strengthening the organic guidelines:

No more synthetic methionine! It needs to be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). Unfortunately, the new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. This is not acceptable! Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

"Inert" ingredients really aren't inert and actually have toxic properties which should not be allowed in the organic industry. These inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. They are designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

No chlorine should be used on organic products. Chlorine is extremely toxic and is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. The NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

I support research into all contanimants and pathways that affect organic farms. Comment to classify: Organically certified de-oiled lecithin is commercially available. Clarkson Soy Products has been supplying it since mid-2013. Its quality and functionality are outstanding. We have not received a single complaint, not even one, about its performance. Processors who want to use available organic ingredients are already using it. Those who continue using conventional de-oiled lecithin are taking unfair commercial advantage over processors using organic lecithin. I suspect resistance to using available de-oiled organic lecithin comes from processors who want the benefit of organic margins while continuing to enjoy the lower cost of using conventional de-oiled lecithin processed with hexane and acetone.

As Clarkson Soy petitioned years ago to remove fluid lecithin from the list of organic exceptions, we were opposed by some processors who made the same claim then that they are making now about de-oiled lecithin. Fortunately, the NOSB saw through those arguments and appropriately removed fluid lecithin from the National List and gave hope to those seeking development of more organic ingredients to replace products made with toxic chemicals. At that time, we anticipated that some processors would continue to avoid buying organic lecithin by claiming they needed de-oiled lecithin. Working with consultants familiar with all lecithin uses, domestic and international, we know that there is almost no application for which fluid lecithin will not work. In a few situations, de-oiled lecithin is more convenient to use than fluid lecithin even though the functionality is identical. But convenience is not supposed to trump the use of certified organic ingredients under the NOP.

Given the availability of fully functional certified organic de-oiled lecithin, continued use of de-oiled conventional lecithin should end gracefully. A staged sunset is appropriate.

Lynn Clarkson
Managing director, Clarkson Soy Products, LLC

Comment to classify: Thank you to the Crops Subcommittee for taking on the problem of manure from conventional farms used on organic farms in its Contaminated Input Plan Discussion Document. The report accurately describes the hazards of this off-farm input.

We believe the only solution to this problem is to ban conventional manure from organic, just as sewage sludge has been banned, and for many of the same reasons.

Conventional manure has for many years been shown to contaminate organic food with arsenic and antibiotics.

This is unacceptable and sadly just the tip of the iceberg. Manure from conventional farms contains all of the waste of the farm, including dead animals and any chemicals used in production or cleaning. Not only that, but composted manure processed by methane digesters has often been mixed in with industrial and slaughterhouse wastes.

The minefield of hazards presented by the use of conventional manure in organic are virtually limitless. A ban is the only acceptable solution.

Please pass a recommendation to ban conventional manure from organic. Comment to classify:
As a Canadian who frequently eats organic produce grown in the U.S., I feel I have a legitimate stake in your agricultural policies. More and more agricultural chemicals are being implicated in environmental crises (like the pollinator collapse) and human health concerns (like the glyphosate link to cancer.) I implore you to keep strong standards for organic growers, and also, because agrichemicals leach into the environment and their residue ends up in even the most pristine land, to support and encourage more farmers to to transition to organic methods. Chemicals, whether old or new, are not the answer. You must enable farmers to learn and develop different agricultural practices. There have been so many advances in soil science, integrated pest management, understanding potential of naturally developed plant varieties, etc. that using chemicals to farm is no longer the most advanced approach. More important, it is not and has never been sustainable to spread toxins in the fields we grow our childrens' food in. Thank you for your attention in this important matter. sincerely, Maria Kasstan

Comment to classify: Ferric phosphate is used as a molluscicide for of slugs and snails. Although harmless to molluscs and earthworms alone as it naturally occurs in soil, ferric phosphate is allowed be combined with chelating agents such as EDTA or EDDS, synergists that make it toxic to snails and slugs, but also earthworms and beneficial soil life.

Therefore, Ferric phosphate should not be used in products labeled as organic. Comment to classify: Synthetic Methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date.

Nonorganic Agricultural Ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

Thank you! Comment to classify: I would like to give my input on the following issues:

1. I support research into all contaminants and pathways of contamination of organic farms. I also support research into ways of preventing contamination, including restrictions on those who are doing the contaminating.

2. Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

3. Synthetic vitamins and other nutrients should be added to organic food only when required by law. Consumers expect superior nutrition from organic food that comes from its production in an ecological production management system that promotes and enhances biodiversity, biological cycles, and soil biological activity. Artificial nutrients are inconsistent with that expectation.

Thank you. Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials. Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).
Disinfectants should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

Protecting Organic Farms from Outside Contamination. I support research into all contaminants and pathways that affect organic farms. I support research into means of preventing the contamination, which must include restrictions on the way other people use many of those materials. Protecting organic farms from outside contamination will require restrictions on what comes onto the farm, but it should also require more responsibility for those who use potentially dangerous materials.

Synthetic vitamins and other nutrients should be added to organic food only when required by law. Consumers expect superior nutrition from organic food that comes from its production in an ecological production management system that promotes and enhances biodiversity, biological cycles, and soil biological activity. Artificial nutrients are inconsistent with that expectation. Comment to classify:
In 1990 when the rules were written for the "organic" fertilizers and soil amendments there were no GMO crops being commercially produced in the USA. All that was required of suppliers of manures, cottonseed meal, bonemeal, etc was paperwork to prove its origin. In 2004 when "GMO" production was addressed there were no changes to the rules concerning the verification that the "organic fertilizers and supplements" not be from, processed with or derived from waste of animals being feed "GMO" crops. As an example of how "GMO" crops have found there way into the organic food supply is that 94% of the cotton produced in the US is "GMO", and 8 states do not allow the use of cottonseed meal as a safe organic fertilizer or organic animal food, how is it that it is still allowed on the national list of acceptable supplements? This is just one example of how contaminated the "organic" fertilizers and supplements are and until a complete toxicology report on all organic fertilizers is required, you are fooling yourselves and the public as to how safe "organic" foods really are. This testing goes for all "organic crop nutritional supplements and manures" and any of these products coming from GMO crops or containing any banned pesticides, growth hormones, antibiotics or any "GE" organisms should not be allowed for use on any organic crops, for your not only contaminating the food being produced but the soil it is being applied to as well as the run-off and ground water. A hydrology study found at : www.hydrol-earth-syst-sci.net/18/333/2014 shows just how damaging the addition of organic matter can be to ground water and currently we are not only polluting it with nitrates but a number of unknown chemicals found in the "organic matter" being applied to the soil. After spending 40+ years in the horticulture industry and currently owning a hydroponic lettuce operation, I've learned that we can always make more soil, but we have never learned how to make more water and until mandatory testing for all Organic Fertilizers is implemented, your Eco-friendly method of farming will continue to be nothing more than a huge marketing campaign. The damage being done to the food and water under the current "organic" rules is no better than that of conventional farming of today. Just because it comes from a living organisms does not make it pure and safe, least we forget that coal and oil came from living creatures at one point in time.

Comment to classify:
I would like to comment on the listing of acidified sodium chlorite (ASC) in combination with lactic acid for use as a topical organic teat dip treatment. I would urge the NOP/NOSB to have this added to the allowable list so these products will be approved and able to be used on organic dairy farms. The current active ingredients that are allowed for organic teat dips do not always provide enough protection against the different pathogens that cause mastitis and/or can lead to drying and irritation of teat skin during wet/cold climatic conditions. We need to consider alternatives as the market has a significant need and we have viable solutions. Let's help the farmers improve milk quality and enhance cow comfort. Comment to classify: I am a mother of two and I go out of my way to buy everything organic that I possibly can due to the high incidence of cancer in my family. Please do not allow "watered down" versions of organics to continue. True organic practices need to be upheld so that consumers can trust the current USDA Organic labeling system. We are depending on this to make the best choices for our families. Therefore, I strongly urge you to consider the following:

Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date. Learn more here.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials. Learn more here.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). Learn more here.

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

Very Sincerely,

Gail C Herath-Veiby Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Gail Veiby --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify: I buy organic food. I want organic food. Please don't let anybody use factory farm waste on organic crops. It should be a privilege for somebody to use the USDA organic label. It will open up a whole new market for them. Please do not deceive your consumers by using products which make this label untrue.

Comment to classify: I am a Post Kidney Transplant patient and I count on Organic Foods to keep my body and second chance at life organ as healthy as possible so that this organ will last the rest of my life (I am in my mid 40's), We as citizens need Organic foods as clean as possible to as not to be contaminated by dirty synthetic chemical pesticides versus conventional non-organic foods.

According to the Organic Foods Production Act, a synthetic substance may only be allowed for use in organic production if it meets the following criteria [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(B)]:

It contains an active synthetic ingredient in the following categories: copper and sulfur compounds; toxins derived from bacteria; pheromones, soaps, horticultural oils, fish emulsions, treated seed, vitamins and minerals; livestock parasiticides and medicines and production aids including netting, tree wraps and seals, insect traps, sticky barriers, row covers, and equipment cleansers.
It contains synthetic inert ingredients that are not classified by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency as inerts of toxicological concern.
Additionally, it must be fully established that the use of the substance [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(A)]

would not be harmful to human health or the environment;
is necessary to the production or handling of the final product because natural substitutes are not available; and
is consistent with organic farming and handling (see the NOSBs Principles of Organic Production and Handling). Comment to classify: April 5, 2015

Dear Dr. Richardson and NOSB Board,

Please accept this letter of support for the proposed addition of zinc sulfate (ZnSO4) for use as a livestock topical treatment material, to the National List of Allowed and Prohibited Substances under NOP 205.603: Synthetic substances allowed for use in organic livestock production.
Zinc sulfate is the most valuable treatment for hoof scald and hoof rot in small ruminants. For sheep, the use of copper sulfate, which is listed as an approved topical on NOP 205.603, is not a recommended practice since copper is toxic to sheep, even at very low levels.
Farmers in the Northeast are often faced with hot and wet conditions when their animals are on pasture. These conditions increase the prevalence of hoof rot in animals. Sheep with foot rot may be unable to stand or walk effectively due to pain, often grazing while kneeling. The need for an effective treatment for animals that are required to be getting 30% of their feed from pasture is critical for animal health.

Sincerely,

A Certified Organic Micro-Dairy Owner Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Erin McWalters --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify:
Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The Livestock Subcommittee (LS) proposal would increase use of synthetic methionine above currently allowed levels without any scientific support. Synthetic methionine is not necessary for animal welfare, but is needed to sustain the factory model of egg and broiler production. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. While the LS proposes a resolution to phase out the use of synthetic methionine, it failed to consider including an expiration date for which the proposal was sent back to the subcommittee and without which the phase out cannot be accomplished.

Comment to classify:
There have been numerous organic farms put out of business due to chemical drift from surrounding farms. Sickly-sweet clouds of pesticide roll through town, and you do not have to look far to find a bee confused and agitated, trying to clean itself as it dies from this pesticide. Here in Saskatchewan we have created a chemical desert. Every year during the growing period, we see crop dusters spraying directly onto red-winged blackbirds that live at the edges of prairie potholes. The tracks from pesticide applicators are all over every crop at all times, and nobody in their right mind would even stroll through the fields because they are so visibly contaminated with chemicals harmful to all life. Put more pressure on the governing bodies to stop the use of harmful chemicals on non-organic farms. The only way to clean things up in a meaningful way is by getting everyone on board with strict regulations against the use of chemicals on all food and farms. That is what people want.

Comment to classify: Please, at least do no harm.

Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date. Learn more here.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials. Learn more here.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). Learn more here.

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

Comment to classify: Thank you to the Crops Subcommittee for taking on the problem of manure from conventional farms used on organic farms in its Contaminated Input Plan Discussion Document. The report accurately describes the hazards of this off-farm input.

We believe the only solution to this problem is to ban conventional manure from organic, just as sewage sludge has been banned, and for many of the same reasons.

Conventional manure has for many years been shown to contaminate organic food with arsenic and antibiotics.

This is unacceptable and sadly just the tip of the iceberg. Manure from conventional farms contains all of the waste of the farm, including dead animals and any chemicals used in production or cleaning. Not only that, but composted manure processed by methane digesters has often been mixed in with industrial and slaughterhouse wastes.

The minefield of hazards presented by the use of conventional manure in organic are virtually limitless. A ban is the only acceptable solution.

Please pass a recommendation to ban conventional manure from organic. - See more at: http://salsa3.salsalabs.com/o/50865/p/dia/action3/common/public/?action_KEY=16140#sthash.7eysDNCZ.dpuf Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Lara Lorenz --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify: 1) Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter. The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices.
2) Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

3) Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

4) Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

5) Protecting Organic Farms from Outside Contamination. There should be research into all contaminants and pathways that affect organic farms. We support research into means of preventing the contamination, which must include restrictions on the way other people use many of those materials. Protecting organic farms from outside contamination will require restrictions on what comes onto the farm, but it should also require more responsibility for those who use potentially dangerous materials.

6) Synthetic vitamins and other nutrients should be added to organic food only when required by law. Consumers expect superior nutrition from organic food that comes from its production in an ecological production management system that promotes and enhances biodiversity, biological cycles, and soil biological activity. Artificial nutrients are inconsistent with that expectation.

Comment to classify:
Ammonium hydroxide should be delisted. It is a serious irritant, toxic by all routes of exposure, known to pollute air and water, contributes to the greenhouse effect, and is toxic to fish and other aquatic species. It is not essential because there are other boiler additives on the National List that can be used for the same purpose, and there are practices that can be used in place of boiler additives. As an unnecessary hazardous substance, it is not consistent with organic production practices.

Comment to classify: My name is Bill Denevan. I work as a grower representative for an organic brokerage company called Viva Tierra based in Sedro-Woolley Washington. I have been with the company meeting with organic growers in Washington,Chile and California for 20 years. From 1976 to 2006 I was a certified organic apple and pear grower with over 100 acres in production. I make it my job to collect information on organic growing practices and network with producers and packers.
Currently I am working with organic growers in California who were forced into experiments to control fireblight with brand new unproven protocols. So far there is plenty of blight in many early orchards even with weather favorable for growers NOT to get blight. I fervently hope that the NOSB does not again implement further bans of essential organic crop protection materials when new substitutes have not been proven.

Materials Organic Growers could not live without:
1. PHEREMONES: In the year 2000 (?) I spoke to the NOSB in Washington D.C. in support. Pheremones are the backbone and cornerstone of all organic tree fruit production. 100% of all organic pear and apple growers now dependant on their use.
2. ELEMENTAL SULFUR: Basic protectant both for Scab and Mildew. Sulfur is a very effective material.
3. LIME SULFUR: Essential for fruit thinning and a contact eradicator of Scab and Mildew. Lime Sulfur is the only material that can be used in organic systems to eliminate scab spores. I used this material successfully for over 30 years.
4. HORTICULTURAL OILS : great for fighting Powdery Mildew, S.J. Scale and Rosy apple Aphid.
5. COPPERS: essential material in our new experiments with Fireblight control.
6. KAOLIN : very effective in controlling Pear Psylla and does a great job protecting fruit from sunburn.

Materials Organic Packers could not thrive without:
1. CHLORINE
2. PARACETIC ACID
3. OZONE

for years organic packers have been nervous about E-Coli, Salmonella and now Listeria. With the current national focus on Food Safety the organic industry has come a long way in addressing this issue. Let's not start banning packing shed materials that are essential to achieving good sanitation. Our industry has worked very hard to build consumer trust. Let's not lose that trust by banning effective food safety materials.

Bill

Comment to classify: Hello,
I'm writing to you tonight as a concerned mother of four children. My concern is that organic food remain truly organic and not have anything synthetic added into it from beginning middle and end in production.
The health of my children is my constant concern and as a conscientious mother I work very hard to ensure that my precious children eat only organic foods. I'm even concerned about organic foods when we go out to eat.
Please keep the organic label as truly organic with no added chemicals. Please keep toxic chemicals not deemed safe or truly natural by the FDA from being included in foods labeled organic. It scares me to think my children could ingest toxic chemicals in their little growing bodies. I do not trust GMO foods at all. I urge you to keep organic truly organic. Public health should be paramount over corporate greed. According to the Organic Foods Production Act, a synthetic substance may only be allowed for use in organic production if it meets the following criteria [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(B)]:

It contains an active synthetic ingredient in the following categories: copper and sulfur compounds; toxins derived from bacteria; pheromones, soaps, horticultural oils, fish emulsions, treated seed, vitamins and minerals; livestock parasiticides and medicines and production aids including netting, tree wraps and seals, insect traps, sticky barriers, row covers, and equipment cleansers.
It contains synthetic inert ingredients that are not classified by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency as inerts of toxicological concern.

Additionally, it must be fully established that the use of the substance [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(A)]

would not be harmful to human health or the environment;
is necessary to the production or handling of the final product because natural substitutes are not available; and
is consistent with organic farming and handling (see the NOSBs Principles of Organic Production and Handling).
Thank you for your time,
Sincerely,

Comment to classify: I am all too well aware of the consequences of consuming gmos, especially canola oil; I was diagnosed with diverticulitis in 1996 while hospitalized because my digestive system had become a pesticide factory. I was being poisoned from within. It took 4 days of some nasty antibiotics in the ICU to get things back on track. I was unable to eat solid food for 2 weeks. All of the heartburn issues which have ballooned over the last 30 or so years are a result of these horrific mutations allowed to invade our daily lives. And it is something which people have looked into, but somehow keeps the truth keeps getting silenced.

If anything, organic standards need to be strengthened. The biotech industry must not be allowed to continue to poison the environment nor our bodies. These companies will stoop to unbelievable lows to hide the facts about their poison producing frankenplants. And the consumers are the guinea pigs for their horrific experiment. One thing is abundantly clear, one cannot wash away what is contained within the plant, part of it's altered biology. How is that ever "Generally Regarded As Safe"? This is pseudo science and it must be stopped. The claims of feeding the world still haven't been delivered, because they are baseless claims.

We need to return to a sustainable farming standard. Stop wasting soil for biofuels. Stop the wanton destruction of bees, butterflies and other important species. Promote a diversity of crops and stop relying on weird pseudo-science for non-existent solutions. We need to support local farms, not corporate farming. And we need to put an end to factory farming along with the abuse of hormones and antibiotics. We need to be more like the rest of the sane world. Comment to classify: Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date. Learn more here. Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.
Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).
Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on theNational List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.
Other key issues we need your help on include:

Protecting Organic Farms from Outside Contamination. I support research into all contaminants and pathways that affect organic farms. We support research into means of preventing the contamination, which must include restrictions on the way other people use many of those materials. Protecting organic farms from outside contamination will require restrictions on what comes onto the farm, but it should also require more responsibility for those who use potentially dangerous materials.
Synthetic vitamins and other nutrients should be added to organic food only when required by law. Consumers expect superior nutrition from organic food that comes from its production in an ecological production management system that promotes and enhances biodiversity, biological cycles, and soil biological activity. Artificial nutrients are inconsistent with that expectation. Thank you!

Comment to classify: I try to purchase organic products not so much for my health, but rather for the health of the planet. I believe we must all do our very best to protect our environment and all its life forms. Therefore I think organic standards should be very specific about what is appropriate in "organic" items. Antibiotics should be prohibited in order to restrict their use for medical necessities. Artificial or synthetic substances, should be allowed only if they are proven not harmful to health of consumers, animals and the environment and if natural substances are not available.

I would also encourage you to put in place provisions to protect organic farmers from contamination by their non organic neighbors. Pesticide drift and cross pollination by genetically engineered crops must be the responsibility of the non organic growers, not the organic farmers.

Thank you for considering my thought on this matter. Comment to classify:
Nonorganic agricultural materials allowed in organic processing and handling are listed as 205.606. Nonorganic Agricultural Ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Many of these materials have never been subject to a technical review. In many cases, the NOSB gave no documentation for decisions, with reviews uniformly ignoring environmental and health impacts of their chemical-intensive agricultural production, including the use of pesticides. Additionally, organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

Comment to classify: Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date. Learn more here.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials. Learn more here.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). Learn more here.

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants. Learn more here.

Do not allow cooperate interest distorte this program. Comment to classify: We are being poisoned every day and I'm sick of it. Big corporations with big money lobbies own our government. Both parties, but mostly republicans by a large margin are guilty. The media, which is supposed to provide us with critical information so we, as and informed populace, can know what to be outraged about is letting us down. The media is the big problem here because if they were doing their job none of this would be possible. But that's not likely to happen when monsanto pays for the news.
We are fed stories about celebrity scandals and cute kittens playing with yarn when we should be watching stories about how giant corporations are poisoning us for profit. Never mind that our police forces across the country are arming themselves as though isis were coming to town and waging war with impunity against the American people.
Sure, we can be hopeful about progress in gay marriage and minimal advances in healthcare. But healthcare is still leaving millions uncovered and those who are covered have a short blanket on a cold night. And don't get me started on school loans.
In Germany, all healthcare and all education, all of it, is free. This is Germany I'm talking about. Remember those guys. We won a war against them and they are doing much better across the board. They don't allow GMOs in their country. They know they are unsafe. All of Europe knows that. Who are these people who chant, "USA, USA, USA" every time someone waves a flag?
What country are they living in? People tell me, if you don't like it, move. But if you stay don't badmouth America. That's being unpatriotic. Patriotism, the last bastion of the scoundrel. I don't know which politician if any will read this message. But if I want them to pay attention to it I need to include a check for an obscene amount of money. That's the only noise those guys can hear.

Comment to classify: The integrity of the organic food label is critical to the maintenance of human health and the environment. The USDA and big food should NOT be allowed to destroy the trusted and quality standards advocated by the NOSB..

Please note some of the major issues before the spring 2015 National Organic Standards Board that could have a significant detrimental impact upon the food we eat, the right to know what we eat, and the environmental impact of these decisions:

Synthetic Methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date.

Non-organic Agricultural Ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA).

Comment to classify:
Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date. Learn more here.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials. Learn more here.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). Learn more here.

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants. Learn more here. Comment to classify: I count on your certification to protect our health by informing me about products I am consuming so that I can make informed choices. I understand that animal wastes from factory farms are allowed in organic compost. This waste is full of heavy metals, antibiotics, pesticides, cleaning chemicals and phamaceuticals, much of which is not destroyed in the composting process. This is wrong and should be reflected in your regulations, either by requiring further testing or just by disallowing wastes from factory farms. Otherwise your certification is meaningless.

Please retain your integrity. It is sorely needed in these times of rampant pollution and corruption!

thank you. Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I respectfully urge you to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law. There is already evidence that 'organic' farms are not following the organic law and it is important to enforce the law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,
Violet R. Comment to classify: To Whom It May Concern:

Below is a statement from "The Cornucopia Institure" with which I agree completely:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,
