Comment to classify:
RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

G. Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that aren't sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

How in the name of all that is decent can people elected to serve the Citizens of this country have such a lack of conscience that they will deliberately POISON those they are SWORN to protect?

Please understand that the organic way of farming and raising animals for consumption is the way things SHOULD BE, and trying to undermine this for the sake of profit is INTOLERABLE.

Do the right thing, and do it now. NO mismanaged cows in organic farms, thank you very much.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

I very much appreciate the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN:

Thank you for this opportunity for input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I definitely support the effort to close loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of conventional livestock being brought onto organic farms. However, the proposed new rule appears to open a new loophole that I feel should be closed. I support the Cornucopia Institute's suggested changes. Specifically, the rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. It must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. It should be fully established, and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. No young transitioned heifers who have never been milked could qualify for sale as "organic."

Should the National Organic Program look for a solution to the potential loophole above, they could choose to ban outright the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from a conventional production to organic production.

And last, but not least. the final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by the creation of additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production. It should only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you, I appreciate your taking the time to read my comments on this very important matter.

Comment to classify: Holy Cow!

The problem with the proposed rule is that USDA bureaucrats define a dairy farm as any farm milking at least one cow! The farm does not even have to be a commercially licensed dairy. Theoretically, a farm could have a single cow that they milk and this would then allow them to also raise thousands of conventionally fed dairy heifers and transition them to organic, before ultimately selling the transitioned animals to the factory dairies already exploiting consumer trust. This would allow the same flagrant abuses to keep occurring.

Cornucopia makes the following suggested changes to the rule:
Require the farm to be a "commercial dairy," inspected and permitted by the state, and have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. Furthermore, the operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves (no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify to be sold as "organic").

An even more powerful and simpler solution would be to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production

I strongly agree with the above, Do your job- Protect Our lands, waters, wildlife, future & health! You work for citizens- Not industry!

Your attention to this most urgent matter would be much appreciated by all present & future generations of all species.

Thank you

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".
Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: To Whom It May Concern:

I agree with The Cornucopia Institutes suggested changes to the proposed origin of livestock rule regarding Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify:
Require the farm to be a commercial dairy, that is inspected and permitted by the state, and that has a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. Furthermore, the operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days; any animal sold must be producing milk themselves (no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify to be sold as "organic").

As put forth by the Northeast Organic Dairy Producers Alliance, to prevent abuse a simpler and even more powerful solution would be to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Regarding the rules pertaining to transitioning breeding stock in hogs and other slaughter species:
I see the need for very limited provisions to bring conventional animals in to diversify genetics. However, the draft proposal could allow operations producing both conventional and organic livestock to shuffle animals back and forth between organic and conventional management. This is completely unacceptable.

Close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that could prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited additions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

I agree with The Cornucopia Institutes suggested changes to the proposed origin of livestock rule. Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

I appreciate the opportunity to provide input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to outside of the standards that we have come to trust under the "USDA Organic" label.

The proposed new rule is not a solution. It appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Robert N. Comment to classify: Dear Sir or Madam:

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this proposed rule.
I am writing to urge that you adopt the changes suggested by the Cornucopia Institute, namely:

Require the farm to be a "commercial dairy," inspected and permitted by the state, and have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. Furthermore, the operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves (no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify to be sold as "organic").

An even more powerful and simpler solution would be to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

thank you,

This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Personally, I long for the day when animal farming is in our remote history. It is abusive and wasteful of resources and immeasurably destructive of our entire ecosystem. The elimination of the greenhouse gases alone could repair our climate. Until that day comes, let's do the best we can.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely yours,
Kurt M. Forman
Clearview Farm
Palmyra, NY

To Whom It May Concern:

Below is a technical and well reasoned comment on the proposed rule regarding the origin of livestock used in organic dairy and meat production which I encourage you to read. I am not a farmer, but I am a consumer of organic products. From reading about the proposed rules and the practices of factory farm operations, I smell a rat. It is perfectly clear that the factory farms are skirting the intentions of the national organics program by continuously bringing in animals bred and maintained by conventional farming practices. I will not purchase any products produced in this way. I will support family farms who follow the spirit and letter of the law and ask that you institute new rules that support these farmers who produce authentic organic food.

I wholeheartedly agree with The Cornucopia Institutes suggested changes to the proposed origin of livestock rule.

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that aren't sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Comment to classify: I believe that maintaining a high level of quality for the organic label is of utmost importance in enabling me to keep myself and my family healthy.

Factory farms, milking thousands of cows each, have been regularly bringing in conventional cattle to both grow their operations and replace animals burned out by their high production management approach. Instead of raising the new animals on organic milk and feed, these cattle are raised on medicated milk replacer that includes antibiotics, and fed GMO grains and hay treated with toxic pesticides. This is not right or ethical. The intent of the proposed new rule is to prevent this practice. I agree with the changes suggested by the Cornucopia Institute. Thank you.

Cornucopia makes the following suggested changes to the rule:

Require the farm to be a "commercial dairy," inspected and permitted by the state, and have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. Furthermore, the operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves (no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify to be sold as "organic").

An even more powerful and simpler solution would be to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for giving me the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock. I have lived on a farm all my life and think it is very important that these abuses be stopped.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: I support the USDAs AMS proposal to amend the origin of livestock requirements for dairy animals under the USDA organic regulations.

With demand for organic products growing rapidly, the market needs to be able to keep up without compromising quality. According to the USDA, the United States is already spending over a billion dollars a year to import organic products. If US wants to compete with foreign markets, we need to encourage farmers to go organic and to convince consumers that US organic products are safe and healthy.

The proposed rules are a step in the right direction. The much needed clarification of the regulation and definitions will allow farmers transition over to organic farming with more confidence. Your report claims that certification and compliance were cited as the most difficult aspect of organic milk production for farms in the Upper Midwest and Northeast. In another section, you stated that audit reports on organic milk operations showed that certifying agents were interpreting the origin of livestock requirements differently. I was surprised to read that half of the certifying agents had one interpretation of the language while the other half had another interpretation. This kind of ambiguity is unacceptable and does very little to encourage organic farming. With agents who are at odds over the meaning of key rules, its not surprising that farmers cite certification and compliance as primary concerns. Not only does the standard need to be precise, but it must also be consistent. The proposed rule would tighten the language and leave less room for such a broad interpretation.

Clarification will also lead to consumer confidence because it allows for more transparency. As mentioned in the previous comments, consumers expect organic milk to be produced without the use of excluded methods and substances prohibited under the regulations. They also mentioned that organic dairy products were keystone products for consumer confidence and a major stepping-stone to additional purchases in other organic categories. This is easy to believe when examining the statistics provided in your report that show organic dairy as the second largest sector in organic retail sales. It makes sense that organic dairy would be heavily scrutinized. There is a lot of misinformation on what is and isnt organic not to mention individual interpretations of the term. Strong and clear regulation detailing the process of how a farm transitions to organic will make it easier for consumers to buy with confidence.

I applaud the AMS for choosing not to allow a staggering transition. I agree that it would make the process unnecessarily complicated and add additional burden on the farmers and agencies. It would also greatly increase the chances of contamination.

Clarification on how breeder stock should be managed on organic livestock farms is vital and I support the AMSs proposals and reiterations. Comment to classify: I support the proposed rule National Organic Program (NOP) - Origin of Livestock, docket number AMS-NOP-11-0009. The 1st Quarter 2015 CHOICES article Consumer Demand for Organic Milk Continues to Expand Can the U.S. Dairy Sector Catch Up? describes signs of organic milk shortages by the end of the year. Alarmingly, organic dairy farming in California, which produces 16.8% of the organic milk for the U.S., is declining. The drought, high organic feed grain prices, and strong competition for their land from other high-value commodities might explain the decline in organic dairy pastures in California. However, according to a 2015 Organic Trade Association survey, the organic dairy sector had an almost 11% increase in sales in 2014, with sales reaching $5.46 billion. With the potential reduced supply of organic milk coupled with increased consumer demands, consumers should feel confident that there is consistency in the transition of dairy animals into organic production.

The cost of raising an organic dairy animal is more expensive than raising a conventional animal. While it may be cheaper to purchase conventional replacements and transition them, if this practice is allowed on a continual basis, it could provide for reduced incentive to produce organic dairy replacement animal. If producers are able to transition animals on a continual basis, consumer confidence may go down due to lack of consistency. It seems reasonable to allow producers to get new organic animals from other dairies with transitioned animals, or animals that were treated organically from the last third of gestation.

I also support linking the transition to a given producer as opposed to linking a transition to a specific location. If the transition was linked to a particular farm, then this could create problems for record keeping. It would be easier and more efficient to link the transition to a producer (individual or corporation). A certifying agent would be more able to keep track of a transition that occurred under a person as opposed herds on a specified piece of land. Also, linking a transition to a physical location could drive down the prices for dairy farms when a producer is selling the land. If a producer has already transitioned animals on that particular site, this could be a disincentive for another producer, who might want to eventually transition animals, to purchase the land.

As current regulations address some of the responsibilities of the certifying agents (e.g. whether animals are organically managed from the last third of gestation and record-keeping), the added responsibilities for certifying agents under this rule should be minimal. Good record keeping, communication, and training staff to examine production history should not be too much of a burden to implement this rule. I also agree that as of the effective date, producers who are certified would be allowed to complete an ongoing transition. Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that aren't sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Courtney E Mendiola

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that arent sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.
Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

While I have used the suggested wording provided by an advocacy group, I am stating most plainly that I ask for loopholes to be closed to help maintain the integrity of the meaning of "organic". I just recently surrendered my organic certification over mistreatment of the federal cost share (that I should have gotten and didn't) and have been looking closely at the program which seems to be rife with loose enforcement and loopholes (largely which serve "big ag"). If this continues, there will be no integrity in the USDA Organic label at all and it's intent will backfire. We have a health crisis largely caused by people (most especially our children) eating poor diets of processed foods loaded with fat and salt and sugar. Those more enlightened know to "eat organic" but if this program loses the respect of the common people then you will have failed utterly.

On another note: Small farmers don't have much hope unless they market directly to neighbors who not only want organic food but local food. If Big Ag can infiltrate the USDA as they have and co-opt the good name of organic food, maybe that will cause a "sea change" in the way we do agriculture in the future. I myself do not trust the USDA organic label anymore and I am passionate about organic
production on my farm and in what I put in my mouth. Comment to classify:
To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

There are a lot of vested interests in the national food supply chain. Predominately corporations have the money to throw at influencing legislation to foster their all important bottom line. Small farmers do not have this luxury. Consumers do not have this luxury. And yet it is the consumer and the small family operation who are sacrificed to the bottom line. The food supply, the health of this nation's soil and the health care costs the American people should be the paramount consideration, not some corporate bottom line. I urge you to move in a direction that delivers more transparency, more responsibility, more intellectual acknowledgement of the connection between our food and our health.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock.
I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of allowing conventional animals onto
organic farms.

The proposed new rule appears to be inconsistent with the intent and spirit of organic law.

I support banning, outright, the label of organic being available for any heifer or cow that had been transitioned
from conventional production to organic production.

Exceptions like these allow factory farms to continue discounting the welfare of animals, and the health of the environment.
Additionally, people (like me) who pay a premium for organic dairy want to know they are getting organic dairy - not only
for health reasons, but because organic is better for the animal and the environment.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,
Concerned American

Comment to classify: To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that arent sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

I would like to provide input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. However, I think the proposed new rule is insufficient. The concept of transitioning a conventionally-raised cow to an organic dairy is contradictory to the concept of an organic dairy, and should be banned.

Specifically, I support the following change.

* The sale of conventionally raised cattle to an organic diary should be banned; or if it occurs, it should invalidate the organic certification of the dairy until all conventionally raised cattle are removed from the dairy and the milk from those cattle may not be sold as organic milk.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,
Charles E. McCarthy

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter. Comment to classify: My family and I struggle to raise , grow and buy organic products to promote our health and well being and we urge you to close the loophole that allows conventional cattle onto organic dairy farms, even one time. This practice compromises everyone who tries so hard to do the right thing and go truly organic. From the dairy farmers to the consumers, organic is the responsible way to go.
It will have added benefits of reducing all the antibiotics , pesticides and herbicides not only in our dairy products but in our soil and water which everyone depends on for our very lives.
Our family agrees with the Cornucopia Institute in this and many other topics. All the chemicals and drugs mentioned above put us all at risk by polluting our soil , water and our bodies and represent a major threat to the food security of all Americans. We need to trust that foods labeled "organic" are in fact truly organic. Thank you for letting our family voice our opinion. Comment to classify: To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that aren't sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban outright the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:
The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.
Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,
P. Comment to classify: I heartily endorse the alterations proposed by Cornucopia:

Require the farm to be a "commercial dairy," inspected and permitted by the state, and have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. Furthermore, the operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves (no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify to be sold as "organic").

An even more powerful and simpler solution would be to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Comment to classify: To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).
Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. We fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that aren't sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, we support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify: Please see attached file(s) for a letter from many of the organic dairy goat producers.

Some states only have one organic dairy goat producer. It would be a great burden to increase their herds or improve their
genetics. Finding organic goats to purchase is very hard. Trying to find organic goats that are disease free (CAE and CL
especially) is almost impossible. This rule would force some producers to bring degenerative diseases into their herds.
Thank you for giving us, the few organic goat producers in the U.S., this opportunity to voice our concerns. Comment to classify:
RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Programs Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loopholes that have allowed the continued practice of bringing conventional livestock on to organic farms. This loophole has been abused and has allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that are not sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to create a new loophole that I want to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning commercial dairy that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk for no less than 180 days and any animal sold should be producing milk itself. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as organic.

Should the National Organic Program seek a definitive solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.
The final rule should close the loophole for breeding stock by creating additional safeguards that would prevent rotating animals in and out of organic production and only allow periodic and limited editions for genetic diversity (prohibiting the practice of converting first litter sows to organic production on a continual basis).

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Sincerely,

Comment to classify:
I am a 4th generation dairy farmer. We certified to be organic 10years ago. There are many rules that make complete sense and some that don't. The livestock origin rule is one I have a hard time with. Once you are certified there is no way to acquire new animals unless buying them from another organic farm, which is not awful unless you don't have the ability. Whether it is due to costs or closeness to your farm it can be impossible to purchase organically. I agree with this rule in part. It makes sense to not allow animals that are 12month or that are bred to be bought and transitioned, but it doesn't make much sense to me to not allow younger stock to be purchased. It would increase the number of organic animals, but still have over a year before they would be milked. I would propose that say an animal 6months or younger could be bought and permanently identified as transitioned so that the animal could not be sold for meat or fiber organically. Whether that is by brand or tattoo is fine. Then the animal can be used for organic milk production and her offspring would be 100% since she would be on an already certified farm.

Comment to classify: RE: Comment on Proposed Rule on Origin of Livestock (Docket Number AMS-NOP-11-0009; NOP-11-04PR)

To Whom It May Concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to provide public input on the National Organic Program's Proposed Rule on the Origin of Livestock. I fully support the effort to close the loophole that has allowed the continued practice of bringing in conventional cattle onto organic farms. This loophole has been abused and allowed factory farm livestock operations to manage their herds using practices that aren't sustainable and do not promote the health of their livestock.

However, the proposed new rule appears to to see closed to prevent the ongoing abuse of the intent and spirit of organic law.

Specifically, I support the following two changes:

The rule must require that any organic dairy farm selling organic animals be a functioning "commercial dairy" that is inspected and permitted by the state in which it operates. Furthermore, this dairy farm must have a relationship with a licensed milk handler shipping to a licensed dairy plant. In addition, this operation should be fully established, shipping milk, for no less than 180 days and that any animal sold has been producing milk themselves. This means that no young transitioned heifers, who have never been milked, could qualify for sale as "organic".

Should the National Organic Program seek an alternative solution to the potential loophole noted above, they could choose to ban, outright, the sale to an organic operation of any cattle that had been transitioned from conventional production to organic production.

Thank you for considering my comments on this important matter.

Comment to classify: Re: Proposed Rule regarding Exemption of Organic Products From Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion Law: AMS-FV-14-0032-0001 (Dec. 16, 2014) (Federal Register Number 2014-29280) (79 Fed. Reg. 75006 et seq.)
Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on USDAs Proposed Rule regarding Exemption of Organic Products From Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion Law.
I fully support the proposed rule mandated by a bi-partisan vote by both houses of Congress.
These rules give the same opportunity to farms and businesses with split operations (organic and non-organic) as 100% organic operations were granted in the 2002 Farm Bill to request a refund on organic sales assessments. This change corrects unequal treatment of organic certificate holders set by the 2002 Farm Bill.
This exemption will provide a level playing field. It allows organically certified farmers and handlers to use check-off monies to benefit their own operations and future, similar to the benefit that non-organic operations receive from being assessed under the Commodity Promotion Law.
Organics is less than 5% of agricultural production and requires very specific research and marketing. Farmers and handlers carry out a high percentage of direct-to-consumer and other marketing, or conduct research on their own farms.
The exemption process should be as efficient as possible. Information on certified organic operations is now available in real time so certificate holders should only need to apply once for an exemption from the check-off, not every year. Commodity boards can be informed by the NOP when the operation loses its organic certification.
Organics should have a blanket exemption from all Research and Promotion programs.
For Marketing Orders, the organic exemption should be the marketing portion average of all AMS Marketing Orders.
I thank USDA for the speed in developing this proposed rule and urge them to proceed to a final rule as quickly as possible, with immediate implementation. Comment to classify: It is well known that organic products protect workers, soil, water and environment. I buy them almost exclusively. Thus I was grateful to learn that legislation will protect them.

Please keep the process of applying for the exemption from the commodity promotion program as simple as possible in order to encourage organic farming. The agency should grant a blanket exemption from all research and promotion programs and from the average marketing portion of all Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) Marketing Orders.

Do not allow lobbyists to convince you that non-organic commodities will be harmed. People will always purchase a cheaper, if inferior, product.

Thanks to the USDA for developing the Proposed Rule and please quickly proceed to a final rule with immediate implementation.
~

Fruit and Vegetable Program
AMS, USDA

Re:Document Number AMS-FV-14-0032; FRN December 16, 2014, Page 75006; Exemption of Organic Products From Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion Law

The United Dairy Industry Association (UDIA) submits the following comments on the Proposed Rule to modify the organic assessment exemption regulations applicable to the Dairy Research and Promotion Program:

1.The Proposed Rule should explicitly state that the organic exemption applies only to the national dairy promotion program. It is important that producers claiming the exemption understand that obtaining a certificate of exemption from assessment under the new organic exemption regulations will not exempt those producers from any state dairy promotion law or regulation that requires the payment of assessments to a state or regional program. This is not clear from the text of the Proposed Rule and should be clarified. UDIA suggests adding a subparagraph (5) to section 1150.157(a) that states the following:

The exemption shall apply only to payment of assessments under this part. Any producer so exempted shall continue to be obligated to pay assessments required by any state statute or regulation applicable to that producer.

2.The Proposed Rule provides for a partial exemption from Marketing Order Program assessments, but a full exemption from Research and Promotion Program assessments. That discrepancy is fundamentally unfair to Research and Promotion Programs, and, if the Proposed Rule is enacted, will result in those Research and Promotion Programs receiving less assessment funds than they would if the Proposed Rule provided for a partial exemption from Research and Promotion Program assessments. On page 75014, the Proposed Rule revises Section 900.700, which is applicable to Marketing Order Programs, to state the following in relevant part: This section specifies criteria for identifying persons eligible to obtain an exemption from the portion of the assessment used to fund marketing promotion activities under a marketing order. Thus, under the Proposed Rule, a handler subject to a Marketing Order can only be exempt from paying the portion of the assessment used to fund marketing promotion activities, which AMS estimates to be sixty percent (60%). See pg. 75009 (The handler would be exempted from 100 percent of the portion of the marketing order assessment attributed to marketing promotion activities (60 percent).). The handler remains obligated to pay the remaining portion of the assessment.

The Proposed Rule treats Research and Promotion Programs far differently. Marketing Order and Agreement Division
Fruit and Vegetable Program
Agricultural Marketing Service
U.S. Department of Agriculture
1400 Independence Avenue, SW; STOP 0237

Subject: Exemption of Organic Products from Assessment under a Commodity Promotion Law (Docket ID: AMS-FV-14-0032-0038)

Dear AMS Administrator Alonzo,

Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on U.S. Department of Agricultures Proposed Rule regarding Exemption of Organic Products from Assessment under a Commodity Promotion Law. I fully support the proposed rule mandated by a bi-partisan vote by both houses of Congress.

These rules give the same opportunity to farms and businesses with split operations (organic and non-organic) as 100% organic operations were granted in the 2002 Farm Bill to request a refund on organic sales assessments. This change corrects unequal treatment of organic certificate holders set by the 2002 Farm Bill.

This exemption will provide a level playing field. It allows organically certified farmers and handlers to use check-off monies to benefit their own operations and future, similar to the benefit that non-organic operations receive from being assessed under the Commodity Promotion Law.

Organics is less than 5% of agricultural production and requires very specific research and marketing. Farmers and handlers carry out a high percentage of direct-to-consumer and other marketing, or conduct research on their own farms.

The exemption process should be as efficient as possible. Information on certified organic operations is now available in real time so certificate holders should only need to apply once for an exemption from the check-off, not every year. Commodity boards can be informed by the National Organic Program when the operation loses its organic certification.

Organics should have a blanket exemption from all Research and Promotion programs.

For Marketing Orders, the organic exemption should be the marketing portion average of all Agricultural Marketing Service Marketing Orders.

Thank you for the speed in developing this proposed rule. I urge you to proceed to a final rule as quickly as possible, with immediate implementation.

Thank you for your consideration of my comments. Please do NOT add my name to your mailing list. I will learn about future developments on this issue from other sources.

Sincerely,
Christopher Lish

Comment to classify: Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)s Proposed Rule, Exemption of Organic Products From Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion Law (Proposed Rule), and as a supporter of the National Organic Coalition, I also support the Proposed Rule and a recommendation for improvement.

The Proposed Rule Carries Out the Bi-Partisan Directive to Expand and Make Consistent Exemptions from Commodity Promotion Programs for All Certified-Organic Producers.

As USDA is aware, the Proposed Rule is a result of a bi-partisan vote of Congress supporting the expansion of the organic assessment exemption within the Agricultural Act of 2014 (2014 Farm Bill). With the passage of this bipartisan bill, Congress sought to ensure that the commodity promotion exemption for organic producers established under 2002 amendments to the Federal Agricultural Improvement and Reform Act of 1996 (FAIR Act) applied to organically-certified producers.

While previous exemptions only applied to 100% organic producers, the Proposed Rule makes the important shift toward providing organically-certified operations that also market non-organic products (split operations) with the same opportunity to be exempt from paying into any conventional research and marketing programs and the marketing portion of any market orders as those operations that are 100% organic. The Proposed Rule helps to correct the false distinction between split operations and 100% organic producers, which gave some organically-certified farmers and handlers an exemption, but not all certified operations, despite the fact that there is no difference in their organic certification status.

The Proposed Rule Will Not Negatively Impact Conventional Commodity Promotions.

The Proposed Rule Enables Even Broader Support of Grassroots Organic Research and Marketing

One-Time Application for an Exemption -The Proposed Rule Needs to Increase Efficiency and Reduces Eligibility Burdens for Commodity Promotion Program Exemption Applications and Administration.

The National Organic Program (NOP) recently upgraded its system to have information on all certified organic operations available in real time. Capitalizing on this positive technological advancement, the Proposed Rule should increase efficiency and eligibility by taking into account the fact that the commodity programs are all housed within USDA and ensuring that certified organic operations need only apply once for exemption. By cross referencing the records within USDA, the veracity of the claim for continued exemption can be verified with a trigger to inform the appropriate commodity Boards if and when the operation loses its organic certification. The organic certificate continues until it is revoked by USDA/NOP. Comment to classify:
Any actions we can take to promote sustainable organic farming vs. chemical intensive factory farming methods should be taken. All the evidence shows that factory farms are depleting the soils of nutrients, accelerating soil erosion AND global climate change, and exposing farm workers and surrounding communities to dangerous levels of pesticides that end up leaving traces on the food we all eat. This trend has also lead to more unhealthy GMO crops which most Americans are opposed to. Please do all you can to honor the wishes of the citizens and help, not hinder, the organic food industry's growth since that is the only sane path.

Comment to classify: January 31, 2015

Re: Proposed Rule regarding Exemption of Organic Products From Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion Law; Docket No. AMS-FV-14-0032-0001

Dear Sir/Madam:
Thank you for the opportunity to provide comments on the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)s Proposed Rule: Exemption of Organic Products From Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion Law (Proposed Rule), and to express my support of the Proposed Rule as well as a recommendation for improvement.
The Proposed Rule makes the important shift toward providing organically-certified operations that also market non-organic products (split operations) with the same opportunity to be exempt from paying into any conventional research and marketing programs and the marketing portion of any market orders as those operations that are 100% organic. The Proposed Rule helps to correct the false distinction between split operations and 100% organic producers, which gave some organically-certified farmers and handlers an exemption, but not all certified operations, despite the fact that there is no difference in their organic certification status.

In Favor of a One-Time Application for an Exemption -The Proposed Rule Needs to Increase Efficiency and Reduce Eligibility Burdens for Commodity Promotion Program Exemption Applications and Administration.
The National Organic Program (NOP) recently upgraded its system to have information on all certified organic operations available in real time. Capitalizing on this positive technological advancement, the Proposed Rule should increase efficiency and eligibility by taking into account the fact that the commodity programs are all housed within USDA and ensuring that certified organic operations need only apply once for exemption. By cross referencing the records within USDA, the veracity of the claim for continued exemption can be verified with a trigger to inform the appropriate commodity Boards if and when the operation loses its organic certification. The organic certificate continues until it is revoked by USDA/NOP. Having to apply only once for exemption will particularly benefit small businesses that make up over 75% of certified organic operations that are subject to a high paperwork burden because of their organic certification. Additionally, for many commodities the organic program purchasing verification requirement provides yet another reason to support one-time exemption applications as purchasers of agricultural product are required to confirm annually that the farmer has a valid organic certificate and they are also required to deduct any commodity promotion program payment. The exemption from the commodity promotion program should not be unduly complicated or burdensome on small businesses. It must be a blanket exemption from all research and promotion programs and from the average marketing portion of all Agricultural Marketing Service (AMS) Marketing Orders. February 17, 2015

Docket Clerk
Marketing Order and Agreement Division
Fruit and Vegetable Program
AMS, USDA
1400 Independence Avenue SW., STOP 0237
Washington, DC 202500237

Re:Document Number AMS-FV-14-0032; FRN December 16, 2014, Page 75006
Exemption of Organic Products from Assessment Under a Commodity Promotion
Law; Proposed Rule

Docket Clerk:

The National Potato Promotion Board, dba United States Potato Board (USPB), welcomes the opportunity to comment on the proposal to modify the organic assessment exemption regulations under 23 Federal Marketing Orders and 22 Research and Promotion Programs.

After industry consultations to fully assess the implications of this proposal, should it be implemented, the USPB has determined there will be economic implications, not just to the USPB, but also to the organic growers who would qualify under this new rule.

USPB research determined approximately 22 split organic/non-organic potato operations would become eligible for exemption from assessment under the Potato Research and Promotion Program. The net loss in assessment revenue to the USPB is estimated at approximately $38,770.00. Of significant note, several of these operations currently utilize USPB marketing and promotion materials on their organic product packaging and in their organic marketing efforts. This new rule, should it be implemented, would prevent these growers from continuing to use USPB promotional materials on their organic products, thereby losing the marketing leverage of USPB programs to help promote their organic products. One grower, whose operation is approximately 80% organic, and serves on the International Marketing Committee of the USPB Administrative Committee, has commented previously he believes USPB programs effectively promote his organic potato products just as much as they do his non-organic potato products. He views the USPB programs as effectively promoting all potato sectors, regardless of how his potatoes are grown.

In summary, the USPB believes this proposed rule is unnecessary, as it applies to the Potato Research and Promotion Program, as so many organic operations continue to support the USPBs work by utilizing USPB promotional materials on their organic products and in their organic marketing programs. Should this rule become final, and split operations do apply for the exemption, they will no longer be able to use USPB marketing materials in support of their organic products and marketing programs, thereby losing the marketing leverage of USPB programs to help promote their organic products. Further, the proposed rule, if finalized, would reduce USPB assessment collections by an estimated $38,770.00 annually.

Comment to classify: I believe that this is a great step for the Organic markets, to provide a level of exemption from extreme regulation that may add extra costs to the smaller scale farmers that typically are in the Organic markets.

I have a little over three years experience in Organic, Permaculture based farming, and I am planning to purchase a farm, roughly 20-25 acres this year in North Carolina. I believe that enough regulation exists to provide protections for consumers and to ensure that Organic quality products are known and checked to be what they are sold as, but I believe that providing extra layers of oversight that require constant quantification, and inventory analysis of the farm products can be a hindrance for many. I, personally, will be implementing a process of quantification, because I believe firmly in the capabilities of Permaculture, and seek to be another cog in the process of helping America free itself from industrial Agriculture, for both the benefit of the environment, and the health of our people. Some farmers are not at this same level that I believe myself to be at; They are working small homestead projects while farming for the ability to continue funding their personal comfort and ability to leave with relative ease. It is a hard job being an Organic farmer, and we already deal with struggles against cross pollination from Monsanto crops, potential for market crashes on certain products (of which crop insurance will prove to be greatly helpful), and the inevitability of us having to find our own markets, and sell our own produce. I believe that we should definitely be thinking of how to protect consumers, but I believe that the consumers themselves are misunderstanding the market, as better off in a globalized scale. Globalization is certainly an aspect of our world that all of us deal with on a daily basis, but for us to farm and distribute food in a globalized structure will prove to be heavily polluting to our world, and will cause the nutritious foods that we grow to lose some of their nutritive value in time.

I firmly support growing local organics, for local "Megacities," and I believe that in such "Slow-grow local" styles, we will find easement in our continued mission to provide people with healthy food, and provide a healthy Earth.

Thank you for your time,
Stephen J.
