Comment to classify: My name is Troy Brown, President, of Kretz Lumber Co., Inc located in Antigo, WI. These are my original comments and I stand by them today.
There are a few things that are wrong with the proposed Hardwood Check-off program that I wish to point out.
First and foremost, we live in the greatest country in the world. What made this country great was the forethought of our founding fathers to establish a government that allows me the freedom to choose. The reason that this program has gotten this far is that there are those of us that would choose not to participate in this unified program based on our beliefs and assumptions that we will not see higher profits from this program.
Second, our government should not be appointed to regulate anything. Our government in a true capitalistic society should be protecting our property from thieves, our lives from those who wish to harm us, and our liberties. One of the reasons for establishing our own government, stated in the Declaration of Independence sent to the King of England in 1776 was; For imposing taxes on us without our consent.
Finally, Amendment V of the constitution states that nor shall private property be taken for public use, without just compensation. We cannot equate that we will receive just compensation for paying into this program. It is too subjective. What one may deem just compensation another will not believe that they have received just compensation. Therefore, if I believe I am not receiving just compensation and I am forced to contribute to the Hardwood Check-off program, it is violating my rights as established in Amendment V of the United States Constitution and in essence stealing my private property if I choose that I do not support this proposed tax assessment.
Therefore as the President of Kretz Lumber Co., Inc. and its representative in this matter we oppose the proposed Hardwood Check-off program. Additionally, on the premise of the law that is stated above, I recommend to the U.S. Department of Agriculture that the Hardwood Check-off program not be taken to the level of referendum.

Comment to classify: I work for a large vertically integrated Hardwood Lumber company based out of West Virginia and have been in the industry for 15 years. I support this program and hope it comes to a vote sooner then later and is passed.

Comment to classify: I am in favor of the Hardwood Checkoff. I have been in the wood flooring business for 35 years now. During that time I have seen a resurgence in market demand for wood flooring but also a number of substitute products that have come into the market with a wood visual but not made out of wood. Increasingly these products steal business from real wood floors. I am talking about Plastic Laminate, Luxury Vinyl Tile and Ceramic Tile digitally printed to look like wood. These product are looking more and more like the real thing but they are not the real thing. Lots of money is being spent by the makers of these substitute products to mislead the consumer into perceiving them as real wood while we are do very little to counter their claims.

The second thing that I have witnessed is the amount of wood flooring and other wood products that are sourced overseas in areas that are notorious for illegal logging. Products made from wood sourced in these areas are not competing on a level playing field with product made from American hardwoods. The rule of law prevails in America and you cannot lower your raw material cost by using stolen wood. Land in America is privately owned and you cannot bribe law enforcement here to let you cut down someone else's forest without paying the rightful owner. The consequences ripple all the way through the supply chain and affect jobs and taxes here in our country. The consumer needs to hear that our products are legal and sustainable.

The American forest is growing more hardwood timber now than at any time in the last hundred years. All U.S.states are growing more hardwood each year than is being harvested or dieing naturally. There is twice as much hardwood volume in the U.S. today as fifty years ago according to U.S. Forest Service statics. This is not the case in most tropical areas of the world where forests are being depleted at alarming rates. Tropical deforestation is blamed for increasing greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.

We need to tell the American hardwood story to the consumer. We have a genuine, time tested product, that supports our domestic economy and is naturally renewing. It is the original green product. Telling this story is too big a job for one company or even one industry to tackle effectively on their own. We need the power of a sustained program with a consistent message. We have seen Checkoffs work in other industries with other agricultural products. We need the Hardwood Checkoff to ensure our children's future. Comment to classify: Im writing in support of the Hardwood Checkoff and encourage the USDA to publish the draft order for an industry vote this year. Our industry has debated the merits of a checkoff for 5 years. Meanwhile our market share has eroded. Given our highly fragmented industry and underfunded trade associations, our hardwood marketing initiatives have not reached designers, specifiers, building professionals or the general consumer. We need a unified message with sustainable funding. The American Hardwood Export Council (AHEC) promoting American hardwoods overseas proves consistent long-term promotion can move the needle. When speaking with one unified voice vs. thousands of independent companies, everyone benefits through increased market demand, consumer awareness, and public education regarding our renewable hardwood resource. The softwood and paper sector have already approved checkoffs and have ongoing programs. With a sustained long-term and proactive marketing approach we can rebrand hardwoods as aesthetically pleasing, sustainable and renewable. We could afford life cycle analysis and comparative analysis of hardwoods vs. competing materials. For many decades, our industry trade associations have lacked funding for either promotion or research. Trade association and state forestry budgets are contracting. Only a small percentage of mills voluntarily support industry research and promotion. We need a promotion war chest and a developmental pipeline for new applications such as thermo-modified lumber.

Plywood Inclusion in Checkoff
I do not agree with concerns by some sawmill producers on the issue of including plywood in the Checkoff. I believe plywood producers would be benefactors of any hardwood checkoff. Kitchen cabinetry, store fixtures, and architectural millwork all routinely include plywood products and help drive greater lumber usage. The plywood sector should pay their fair share of the hardwood marketing expense. AHEC has promoted generic hardwoods including hardwood veneer and plywood for over 15 years. No one has objected beforehand. The intent of an industry checkoff is to grow the overall hardwood pie. Competing substitute products such as luxury vinyl tile and melamines are aggressively eroding our markets. Without a unified voice and sustainable funding, our message is unheard.

Assessment
In reference to value-added producers, I believe the revised draft language has mistakenly included a mechanism for imputing value of lumber produced internally which is not necessary. Green and/or air dried lumber should be treated as the first step in the value chain. Kiln drying is the second step. Additional integrated value-added producers such as flooring manufacturers, moulding producers, etc. are the third step in the value chain. Comment to classify: We need to get the good news about hardwoods to consumers. Right now they don't have a clue how healthy our hardwood forests are and how diverse, beautiful and environmentally beneficial utilizing hardwood products are.

Opponents and proponents of this order agree our industry needs to educate and promote hardwood products to consumers, and research new hardwood uses/methods of harvesting/manufacturing that will benefit all. We agree that all stake holders from timberland owners to hardwood product manufacturers small and large will financially benefit when consumers realize the amazing diversity, quality and characteristics hardwoods offer, and buy more hardwoods. Our industry, small and large companies will benefit as more consumers learn the incredible environmental benefits utilizing hardwoods gives, and buy more hardwoods.

Since this "check-off" process started, other building materials have taken market share from traditional hardwood uses. Hardwood values have gone on a roller coaster ride, at least in part as demand switched to other materials who present a unified message to consumers. Other agricultural producers, small to large have benefited from their check-off program, it's time to try ours.

This proposed order is the natural step to fund accomplishing the common goals all hardwood stake holders have, a more stable, diverse and growing demand for hardwood products. If it passes now, five years from now we'll be renewing it.

Comment to classify: As a small hardwood sawmill, we are not in favor of the Hardwood Check-Off. The burden for this TAX will rest almost solely on the hardwood sawmills, while the wholesaler will only pay a small percent of the tax levied on the lumber purchased from the sawmill. Indiana has one of the largest populations of small family owned sawmills, and we are at this point struggling to make ends meet, with Group Health Insurance, Workers Comp, General Liability insurance, all increasing at a rapid rate; this tax would force many to shut down their businesses.

An elite group of Lumbermen came up with this idea, to help them pay for their advertising.

We are not in favor of the Hardwood Lumber Check-off.

Ford Frick
Frick Lumber Co., Inc.

Comment to classify: I previously submitted comments with my opposition to the original Order in 2013/2014. Many others also submitted comments that I agreed with that reinforced my opposition. Nothing that I can understand from these proposed revisions has changed my opinion. Either the concerns I had were not address to my satisfaction, or they are difficult to discern from the way they are being presented. For example:

In the Revised Order, under the Referenda heading, it states: USDA is proposing to modify the referenda criteria as specified in the November 2013 proposed rule in paragraphs (a) and (b) of proposed 1211.81 to require approval by a majority of manufacturers voting in the referendum who also represent a majority of the volume (board foot or equivalent) of covered hardwood, represented in the referendum and by those who, during a representative period determined by the Secretary, were engaged in the manufacturing of covered hardwood.

What exactly is this saying? Is it a weighted vote or one vote for one company?

The National Hardwood Lumber Association, whom remains neutral on this issue, issued a release to its members trying to inform them of the Revised Hardwood Lumber and Hardwood Plywood Promotion, Research and information Order. After their comments about the voting changes, they stated (Note: We asked USDA for clarification on this and were told there would be none until after the comments)

How can I make an informed comment about this proposal if the USDA will not clarify this important issue?

I can comment on the hardwood plywood inclusion. Plywood is a direct competitor of my solid hardwood products. They should not be included in any form.

My comments about the assessments are not directed solely at the computation. My original opposition to this Order was that the under $2,000,000 in sales manufacturers were exempt. Now even more hardwood manufacturers will not have to pay. Any way you calculate it, either everyone pays or no one does.

I continue to oppose the original Order and the Revised Order. None of these proposed revisions has changed my mind.

Bucky Pescaglia
President
Missouri-Pacific Lumber Co, Inc.

Comment to classify: The proposed Hardwood Lumber and Hardwood Plywood Checkoff, as it is now presented, is a water-down version of an idea that was conceived during the worst financial downturn any of us working in the business today has ever seen. Decisions that will have long lasting impacts are usually not well thought through during times of turmoil. The Proposal, if adopted as now written, will raise very little money (at least for a meaningful promotional program) and will be administered by a board that has far too many people on it to make good decisions.

Some claim that we should try it and if we don't like it, we'll just change it or get rid of it. The process that we're all still talking about has taken 6 or 7 years from conception to this point. How long might it take the industry to change or eliminate what is set in motion now? One thing is for certain, we'll all still be paying each year as the changes or elimination debate goes along.

Without the proposed Checkoff our industry will go through good times and not such good times, as it always has. Does anyone actually believe this Proposal, as now written, will have any impact of the prosperity of our industry? Does anyone believe the small quantity of money that will be generated and then split up many ways for many pet ideas will have any impact on the laws of Supply and Demand that rule our industry I for one, do not! This morning I read the Washington Post article about the paper checkoff and all of the great ads targeting my millennial age group. I  also suggest the industry run these on Pinterest and HGTV where many of my friends go to get product ideas.

Comment to classify: I am writing on behalf of AJD Forest Products to express our continued opposition to the proposed Hardwood Lumber Check Off tax. We can not imagine a "Check Off Board" developing a marketing plan that would benefit our business.

The diversity of hardwood species, diversity of species characteristics and diversity of hardwood usage makes comparisons of a Hardwood Lumber Check Off to check off programs for homogeneous farm grown commodities impossible.

Marketing our hardwood lumber products is not an issue we see as limiting our viability and growth. However, if we must divert marketing funds we are currently spending very effectively to a socialistic collective spending money on what is best for the "Check off Board" we will have a business problem to address.

As a company, AJD Forest Products has stated its opposition to proposed Hardwood Lumber Check Off tax during every comment period and subsequent extended periods.

It is time to let the industry reject this proposal. Get the proposed Hardwood Checkoff to a vote. Comment to classify: Having spent an entire career at Pike Lumber Company, I understand the value of research, promotion, and information
that a check-off program would bring to the hardwood industry. As stated in earlier comments I strongly support the check-off
program.
As a fully integrated hardwood manufacturer from growing and managing forest land through logging, sawmilling, kiln drying
warehousing, and distributing, I recognize the need to include the hardwood plywood industry with hardwood lumber since we
both rely on the hardwood resource for our products. The hardwood plywood industry does not compete with the lumber
industry but rather compliments it in bringing value to the hardwood resource. Projects that specify hardwood plywood usually
also use hardwood solids from lumber and gives designers an alternative to competing raw materials such as concrete, plastic,
glass, and steel. Comment to classify: I am President and CEO of Resources First Foundation, and I strongly and whole heartedly endorse approval of the Hardwood Lumber and Plywood Promotion, Research and information Order.

I live and work in Maine, an important hardwood forest state.

The U.S. has the healthiest hardwood forests in the world and Maine has the healthiest forests of any U.S. state, over 17.5 million acres (16.258 million are privately owned); it is no coincidence that our forests are healthy and productive. Maine also hosts the largest conservation easement acreage of any state (2,338,266 acres). Earlier in my career I worked on the Pingree easement (762,000 acres and the Downeast Lakes easement (342,000 acres). The Pingree family which owns Seven Islands Land Company has two hardwood mills in northern Maine, which are operating profitably in large part due to a successful marketing strategy.

My foundation, Resources First Foundation hosts over 3,200 consulting foresters nation-wide. We believe in promoting sustainable forestry and supporting the businesses dependent on US forests. Comment to classify: I am the Executive Director of the Missouri Forest Products Association (MFPA) and I represent over 350 forest products industries in Missouri. My membership is primarily comprised of small to medium sized sawmills, logging companies, and secondary manufacturing firms. MFPA membership is 100% in opposition to the Hardwood Lumber and Hardwood Plywood Promotion checkoff that is being proposed by the USDA. The proposed checkoff should be eliminated completely, no revisions will be found suitable for our membership.

It seems fundamentally wrong to force an industry to support a government program that they do not believe in and do not believe that they will receive a direct benefit. I completely understand that USDA is responding to a group of forest products industry owners that brought the concept of a checkoff forward for consideration. Unfortunately, this group did not adequately gather the thoughts of the entire industry prior to submission of their concept. MFPA members want to speak for themselves, and the message is loud and clear, we do not want or need a checkoff.

If USDA does not have the wisdom to "pull" this order from consideration, then we should quickly move forward to a vote. The vote must be fair, which is one company should receive one vote, regardless of reported sales figures and volume produced. This process is now approaching 2 years and it has become a divisive issue within the industry, it is time to move on. Comment to classify: Upon first glance I have a few questions and suggestions.

1- Overall there seems to be a lack of understanding in regards to hardwood and hardwood manufacturing. Hardwood plywood and hardwood lumber are separate products competing for the same end use. For these to be linked is counterintuitive. Plywood and lumber compete for the same resources and final sales. In many cases plywood frame stock has replaced many interior components of solid lumber. As I read the proposed order, engineered flooring will be excluded. Is there a chance engineered flooring will receive the upside of marketing because of the lack of consumer education?

2- In the proposed order it calls for research of our resources. This information is readily available through the Forest Service. Is it necessary to reproduce what has already been done?

3- By exempting log export sales the USDA will be encouraging the added value to products to be done in other countries thus meaning a loss of US jobs. Is that the mission or goal of the USDA?

4- Furniture products are non assessed unless the furniture manufacturer dries their own lumber which meets the definition of a "hardwood manufacturer." Are they apart of the vote? Will they be notified? If so, in what form will they be notified?

5- Exports are included but imports are excluded. Is there a possibility importers will benefit from this proposal?

6- Everything 3A will be taxed, but furniture is excluded. Therefore if 1Common goes to a furniture factory will it be included or excluded?

7- Lastly, is it possible to get someone with industry knowledge to write this proposal so that we might avoid unintended consequences to well meaning intentions? Comment to classify: Hardwood Lumber and Hardwood Plywood Promotion, Research and Information Order
Proposed Rule
Comment from Mr. John Williams, CEO, Domtar, Inc.
My name is John Williams and I am CEO of Domtar, Inc. headquartered in Fort Mill, South Carolina. Domtar designs, manufactures, markets and distributes a wide variety of wood fiber-based products, including communication papers, specialty and packaging papers, and absorbent hygiene products. In 2014, Domtar had sales of $5.6 billion from some 50 countries. The Company employs approximately 9,800 people. I offer comments on behalf of Domtar in strong support of the proposed Hardwood Checkoff Program and applaud the United States Department of Agriculture for moving forward with this proposal. I urge the United States Department of Agriculture to allow this program to go to an industry vote as soon as practical.
In late 2013, the paper and paper-based packaging segment of the forest products industry voted overwhelmingly to adopt an USDA check-off program. It became effective on January 23, 2014 and I have the privilege of chairing the Board that is overseeing and directing our new initiative. This program, in a short period, has exceeded expectations in reaching end customers and users of our products.
Domtar is a significant user of hardwood residual materials. I believe a hardwood check-off program will go a long way toward bettering the outreach, messaging and financial gain of both the hardwood industry, as well as the entire forest products industry.
Within the forest products industry, the hardwood sector shares similar positions to the paper and packaging sector. Consumer and customer misconceptions and increased competition are seen as factors in a significant decline in hardwood sales. Individual companies are fighting this decline on their own, but their influence will be limited at best. For the same reasons it was the right decision for the paper industry, I view the establishment of a check-off program for the hardwood segment as the best way to combat diminishing sales. The larger audience, unified message, and greater financial gain of a check-off program are exactly what the hardwood industry needs.
A hardwood check-off program will also help to unify the nation's forest products industry. A unified industry - one in which paper, softwood lumber, and hardwood have all established check-off programs - would offer a face of resilience and endurance to the public never before seen.
As a member of the forest products industry, the hardwood industry is facing the same marketing and communications challenges as the paper and packaging sectors. I hope the hardwood industry will be allowed to pass a vote in favor of a Checkoff program to effectively compete and resume its important and rightful place in the mix of forest products consumers choose.

Thank you for this opportunity to comment.

John D. Williams, President and CEO

Comment to classify: After reading the revisions I still remain strongly opposed to the proposal. The initial plan was flawed, cumbersome and poorly written. The changes to the proposed order has only revised the ineptitude and made it more difficult to understand. The language is written in a manner to confuse readers and ultimately voters. Many of the initial questions remain unaddressed even after an industry webinar.

For example review the voting process. "USDA is proposing to modify the referenda criteria as specified in the November 2013 proposed rule in paragraphs (a) and (b) of proposed 1211.81 to require approval by a majority of manufacturers voting in the referendum who also represent a majority of the volume (board foot or equivalent) of covered hardwood, represented in the referendum and by those who, during a representative period determined by the Secretary, were engaged in the manufacturing of covered hardwood."

This language is absurd. The USDA is asking to help an industry but can't give a clear understanding of how the votes will be counted. My question is simple; is the voting process one vote for one company or weighted?

If the USDA can't clearly state how the voting process will be handled then they are in no position to have influence regarding the direction of this industry. Comment to classify: Virginia Forest Products Association represents over 300 forest products industries conducting business in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Our membership is primarily comprised of independently owned and operated small to medium sized sawmills, logging companies, and secondary manufacturing companies. The VFPA membership, as polled in February 2015, is 98% in opposition to the proposed Hardwood Lumber and Hardwood Plywood Promotion Checkoff. As the proposal has been highly controversial, divisional and damaging to a previously close-knit industry, the proposed Checkoff should be terminated immediately, as no revisions will be found acceptable for those split by this Order.

At the core of the opposition to the proposed program, our membership does not embrace the Checkoff program nor have they evidence supporting a direct benefit to their businesses. While the USDA has responded to a select group of industry members' calling for the Checkoff, prior industry polling (National Hardwood Lumber Association) has concluded an overall distaste for a mandatory program. The industry has local, statewide, and national marketing and promotional organizations to chose from (i.e. National Hardwood Lumber Association and American Hardwood Export Council) for domestic and export marketing programs. Various other trade organizations represent groups by regions and species (i.e. Virginia Forest Products Association and Appalachian Hardwood Manufacturers) to increase awareness of the highly specialized uses of a select hardwoods among the many existing. Forced participation into the proposed Hardwood Checkoff program would have detrimental affects upon these preexisting organizations. Of note - voluntary contributions to alternative promotion programs are often credited to assessment payments within commodity Checkoff programs; such is NOT the case for the proposed Hardwood Checkoff.

The membership of Virginia Forest Products Association remains opposed to the current proposed Hardwood Checkoff and requests either 1) the immediate termination of this Order with limitations on minimum industry acceptance prior to resubmission or 2) a fair and equitable immediate industry vote.

Susan R. Jennings
President
Virginia Forest Products Association

Comment to classify: i fundamentally opposed to the Hardwood Checkoff. Forcing a tax on everyone to benefit a few is not what checkoffs were suppose to accomplish. The hardwood industry is too diverse and if these large companies want to spend their money on research and promotion that is what they should do. The company I work for spend lots of money on research and promotion already and we are small enough part of the hardwood industry that our money for the program would only go to promote their products not our own. These companies that propose this are wanting to tax everyone to pay for what is just part of business for everyone else. I know that checkoff's can be very valuable tool in industries that have very specific products. Unlike the beef industry the hardwood industry is not all selling similar products and it is not even possible to take the money you will collect and make it apply to research and promotion to benefit every producer in the industry. I feel that the program if passed would need to be narrowed to a more like group of producers. It is very similar to saying you are going to have a checkoff for the vehicle industry. Large tractor trailers do not have the same research and promotion needs as the economy car industry. If it comes to a vote I feel that it should be one company one vote. I have great concerns with this as well as my company was only notified about the promotion through the MFPA we were not contacted by the USDA so how would you know if every company would even get to vote. I think the rule need more work and needs to be a narrower group to be as truly effective as some of the other programs that have shown to be effective.

Comment to classify:
My name is David Gilliam. I've worked as a project engineer in the hardwood lumber industry for 30 years, the past 17 for Northland Forest Products. I have witnessed how the milk, beef, soybean, and pork industries have benefitted from checkoff programs, and I am convinced that a similar program for hardwood lumber is necessary to educate the next generation of consumers in the value that American hardwood lumber represents. No other material is sustainable and offers the beauty, character, and versatility of solid hardwood. Our industry is fragmented and without a solid front the story is not going to be told to the ones who are making purchasing decisions.  A checkoff program can have a positive effect on the future of the hardwood industry by assuring people that hardwood is a good choice.

Comment to classify: There is a standard all divisions of government should adopt: PRUDENCE.

Rather than making aggressive and too often self-serving changes, we ought to consider what is PRUDENT?, what is REASONABLE?, and of course, how will our actions affect future generations?

We know that we have exploited and damaged the Earth in places in a way that is going to require future generations to clean up after us---MANY future generations (consider, for instance---just as one example---the PCBs left behind in the silt of the magnificent Hudson River by General Electric Company. What a predicament! Can't leave the problem alone and can't clean it up, at least not with current technology---what a PREDICAMENT!). Is it really in our BEST INTEREST to steal the birthright of many future generations---at least, quite honestly, any more so than we already have?

Do we really need to complicate the lives of generations even yet unborn? Is that fair? isn't living life complicated enough, even without paying off a tremendous debt left by our forebears?

Growing food without the use of enduring pesticide residues is simply a PRUDENT practice, that benefits anyone who eats such produce, and protects our Earth from untenable accretions of poisons.

I urge the National Organics Standards Board to maintain PRUDENT and healthy standards, and certainly to tighten standards wherever we discover we are taking lazy and potentially dangerous shortcuts. Keep the BACKBONE in your policy. Comment to classify: Re: Humic Acids

Dear Advisory Committee,

We are an organic pecan grower and processor in southern Arizona. Humic materials play a key role in our organic fertility program. Humic molecular structure enables larger water holding capacities in the soil and makes nutrients (especially phosphorous) available from our compost that we apply. Additionally, the water holding capacity of humic molecules assists in leaching our salts that we encounter in our high pH western soils.This same characteristic also increases our irrigation efficiency and maximizes our applied water. Humic materials continue to improve our soil structure by providing a carbon source for micro organisms and over all soil health. We encourage the committee to allow the use of humic acids in organic production.

Thank you,
Brian Driscoll
Farm Manager
Farmers Investment Co./Green Valley Pecan
PO Box 217
San Simon, AZ 85632

We do not know other alternative with the effectiveness of flowering as ethylene.
Less effective pollution caused by planting steady income.
Uniformity in the crop is vital for the proper marketing and project profitability.

Increased farmers to research and marketing of inputs is profitable for providers is needed. Ethylene removal would kill an activity before you take your adolescence.

Ethylene remove organic pineapple would be sacrificing a market that is just beginning.

I appreciate the consideration of my comments to continue using the ethylene flowering of pineapple

Comment to classify: My name is Alejandra Muoz and I work for CANAPEP (National Chamber for the Production and Export of Pineapples) that represents over 80% of the volume of Costa Rica's conventional and organic pineapple production and exports. Our members include small, medium, and large growers of organic pineapples in Costa Rica.
Regarding the effect of the elimination of ethylene in the production of organic pineapple:

There are no alternatives to change this material and the activity could be not rentable.
The use of ethylene prevents the NDF (Natural Flowering) in commercial plantations that causes economic losses because there are different times of flowering making it a difficult and disorganized harvest.
Furthermore, eliminating ethylene will increase costs and will force many manufacturers to be less competitive or even go out of business.
There are no documented cases of harm to public health or workers caused by ethylene.
We consider this material is critical for the production of Costa Rican organic pineapple and the non-inclusion in the National List would put in danger our production, employment, and family well-being.

Comment to classify: I am a mother of a young son who has food sensitivity issues. Switching to only organics has made a significant improvement to his life and health. Please keep Organics STRONG and protected.

Keep the integrity of Organic items intact. The following are four things that need to be studied and/or in-acted to keep organic products safe.

Synthetic methionine should be phased out of organic poultry feed as the NOSB originally decided. Methionine is an amino acid that acts as a growth promoter (comparable to the synthetic growth promoter rGBH used in dairy cows). The new proposal increases use instead of increasing space and outdoor access, and alternative feed sources without any scientific support. Neither synthetic amino acids nor synthetic growth promoters are compatible with organic practices. The phase out requires an expiration date. Learn more here.

Nonorganic agricultural ingredients in organic products should be eliminated based on health and environmental impacts and the ability to produce them organically. Documentation for decisions has been lacking, including environmental and health impacts of pesticides used in their production. Organic agriculture can now supply most, if not all, of these materials. Learn more here.

Inert ingredients in pesticides used in organic production must be individually reviewed without further delay, according to processes recommended by the NOSB. So-called inert ingredients in pesticide products are neither chemically nor biologically inert, but designed to enhance the pesticidal activity of pesticide products and can have toxic properties that do not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). Learn more here.

Organic should be chlorine-free, to the extent possible. Chlorine is hazardous in its production, transportation, storage, use, and disposal. EPAs Design for the Environment has identified safer viable alternatives for some or all uses, including other materials on the National List. It is time for the NOSB to update its thinking and approach to cleaners and disinfectants.

Thank you,

Comment to classify: There are far too many exceptions on organic food. The idea of organic food was not to benefit the industry. It was to eat cleaner food. How can we, who are not farmers, live better lives, when those of you who are specialists are not strict enough to advocate on our behalf?

In the meantime, why isn't it required that everything that has the USDA Certified Organic logo on it be labeled with EVERYTHING that has been used on it up until the point it reaches the retailer?

We deserve to know that bananas are with ethylene, one of the less troublesome allowances. OR sulfur dioxide may be present. Why is not a sign required in every retailer's store in full view of every counter that holds produce revealing that the produce has such and such on it or was treated with such and such even though it evaporated?

It's our right to know.

The biggest problem with not having a labeling requirement for every showcase of every retailer of organics is that retailers have no idea what's on the produce, so we can't ask the retailer. Retailers are not required to give a phone number of a producer or finisher, so, most of the time, we have to go hunting the number down to call them and they end up saying they don't even know what's in the combination chemical they use from such and such a company. So the poor consumer who calls about only 1 piece of produce a day has to endure 5-10 phone calls to get one answer and rarely gets an answer at all.

What if we are allergic to xantham gum? How will we know whether there is any present? OR what if we choose not to eat produce that has xantham gum? How are we to know?

Please help by making producers pass on their pesticide, herbicide, fungicide, wax/coating list. And then there's beeswax. Can't we make a rule that animal product must be labeled as such so that we can choose our produce without 10 phone calls for one piece of produce a day?

Thank you for your help. Comment to classify: Organic products are a priority choice for me due to the prevalance of chemicals, pesticides, and chemical fertilizers in all non-organic products. I made a conscious choice to stay away from these materials for better health for myself and those I love.

According to the Organic Foods Production Act, a synthetic substance may only be allowed for use in organic production if it meets the following criteria [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(B)]:

It contains an active synthetic ingredient in the following categories: copper and sulfur compounds; toxins derived from bacteria; pheromones, soaps, horticultural oils, fish emulsions, treated seed, vitamins and minerals; livestock parasiticides and medicines and production aids including netting, tree wraps and seals, insect traps, sticky barriers, row covers, and equipment cleansers.
It contains synthetic inert ingredients that are not classified by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency as inerts of toxicological concern.

Additionally, it must be fully established that the use of the substance [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(A)]:

would not be harmful to human health or the environment;
is necessary to the production or handling of the final product because natural substitutes are not available; and
is consistent with organic farming and handling

We must keep organic strong in order to save the bees, maintain biodiversity and clean water, and keep the air clean, all of which are protected by organic standards. We must also keep organic strong to protect our environment as well as all of its' inhabitants.

Thank you for reviewing my comments. Comment to classify: I oppose the proposal to classify laminarin as nonsynthetic, which would permit its use without examination of hazards.
Not only do I believe that the manufacturing process qualifies this material as a synthetic material, but there are also issues
of health and safety that the Board should evaluate as it moves forward in determining whether these materials should be
recommended for allowance in organic production. Laminarin is extracted from seaweed and is also found in fungi.
Laminarin works by amplifying natural plant defenses and by increasing the concentration of anti-herbivore and antifungal
metabolites, such as the toxic chemical solanine in potatoes. The subcommittee has not addressed the issue of whether
laminarin and seaweed extracts might result in levels of exposure to plant-defensive chemicals that could prove toxic to
consumers, but also result in levels of exposure that are toxic to pollinators. Comment to classify: We are a fairly new farm, and we farm several hundred acres of organic vegetables, and we have an interest in these potential Sunseting materials.
We do not use all of these at the present time, but we may have need them in the future.

Hydrogen peroxide: This is a useful tool for sanitation of vegetables, tools, equipment and structures.

Copper, fixed: This is truly indispensable for potato disease control in our climate, also useful for our organic Brussels sprouts.

Vitamin D3: this remains the only organically-approved rodent control bait that I am aware of.

Boron and Manganese are used often in our region. Boron leaches away over time, and the others (Zinc, Molybdenum) are in our soils at insufficient levels in places.

Liquid fish products: There are not many liquids we can use on our crops. Fish is one source we may use.

Insecticidal soaps: We grow cole crops which are waxy and difficult to spray. The soaps kill aphids and greatly improve in wetting the leaves.

Chlorine dioxide and Ozone are potentially important tools for preserving our potatoes in storage.

Ethylene is a naturally-occuring compound we may need for managing stored potatoes.

Humic acids: These are derived from natural sources and can be effective at enhancing plant growth, and increasing the efficiency at which plants use soil nutrients.

Calcium chloride is useful for maintaining internal quality of fruits and vegetables. I don't know how effective other calcium products are, but most are derived from Calcium chloride.

Citric acid may be useful for us as a tool for solublizing phosphate rock powder to create readily available phosphorous for our crops.

Thank you.
Bill Swanson

Comment to classify: I am Eng. Christian Herrera, General Manager of Coopeproagro R. L, a 21 growers coop of organic pineapple production, located in the norht plains of San Carlos county, in northern Costa Rica... Our coop is actually growing 125 acres of certified organic pineapple for exports to the U.S and Europe as well....
Conventional Pineapple Production is a very intense operation even with its crop protection package that includes all kind of chemical controls.And when refferring to organic pineapple production, its much more challenging to growers since being a humid tropical region the pressure the crop has on pests and diseases is much bigger, with a very narrow choice of options for nutrition and pests control .
In pineapple, flower induction in organic production, had been done with ethylene gas which is now our only option. The ethylene is used mixed with active charcoal ( as an inoquate transport agent ) , so the plantation flowers all even, so controlled harvest can be done 22 weeks after flower induction.
Ethylene use in pineapple is one of the safeties applications on crop, very unlikely to raise a workers hazzard or environmental risk .So far there is NO RESEARCH, being held to look after substitutes, since its used is not questioned due to hazards risk to field personnel nor environment.

Its our clear position to support the use of Ethylene in organic production since its the only option there is so far. Not having Ethylene will definitively mean the end of our business and the loss of 200 employees in the most needed region of the northern plains of Costa Rica. Comment to classify: 205.605(a) & 205.605(b) - Support for continued use of the following materials as they are essential for the manufacturing of products:
Bentonite - needed as a filtering aid for specific fruit juice concentrates. No other alternatives available
Diatomaceus Earth - needed as a filtering aid for specific fruit juice concentrates. No other alternatives available
Enzymes - needed in the processing of fruit juice and concentrates. No other alternatives available
Flavors- Smucker Natural Foods, in the 1990's, was the first company to develop an "organic" flavor. Since that time we have been dedicated to only using organic flavors in our finished products. We fully support the annotation change adding commercial availability to the annotation.
Flavors should not be removed from the National List - rather the annotation changed to reflect commercial availability. In the past 15 years of using organic flavors we have never had a problem sourcing by quality, quantity, and form. However, we agree that there may be some applications where commercial availability is still an issue.
Nitrogen - used for packaging. No other alternatives available
Perlite- needed as a filtering aid for specific fruit juice concentrates. No other alternatives available
Sodium bicarbonate - used in baking. No other alternatives available.
Ascorbic Acid- used as an antioxidant in fruit products. No other alternatives available
Carbon Dioxide - used to carbonate fruit juice beverages. No other alternatives available
Chlorine Materials - used as a sanitizer when PAA is not an alternative.
Ethylene - used to ripen pineapples. This is critical for the continued supply of organic pineapple juice. If ethylene is removed from the National List then we will no longer have a supply of pineapple juice.
Glycerine - used in the manufacturing of flavors. This is critical for the continued use of flavors.
Hydrogen Peroxide - used in aseptic packaging. This is critical for the continued use of aseptic packaging. No alternatives
Nutrient Vitamins and minerals - used to fortify vitamins A,C,E. No alternatives available.
Xanthan Gum - used as a thickener in juice products. No alternatives available.

In my case when I need to apply the pineapple plants with Ethylene gas. I to rent a spray external service with a cheap

Comment to classify: Farm Name: Pias Orgnicas SOGO S.A.

Location (state and/or Country): Costa Rica

Your e-mail: luisgonza@ice.co.cr

1.Do you or the growers you work with utilize ethylene gas for regulation of pineapple flowering?:
If correct, ethylene is the only practical means of obtaining homogeneous organic pineapple flowering.

2.How and when is ethylene gas used on your farm or on the farms you work with?:
Ethylene gas is applied 6 months before harvest of the fruit, or 8 months after planting pineapple. This is applied with a small tank mixture sprayed with water carrier and activated carbon to try to retain the gas and the maximum hours of low temperature to gas does not volatilize very quickly and can make the effect of inducing bloom.

3.Why is ethylene gas necessary for the success of your farm's production or the production of the farms you work with?:
Ethylene is very important because it is the only way to standardize production, also to program customer sales.
If you do not use ethylene to induce flowering of pineapple, flowers appear only when there is short photoperiod and low temperatures, a condition that occurs only in December so there would only be fruits six months later, i.e. in June and only this month because all would bloom in December. Thus we cannot supply the market every week as I do and would have to leave this small business because in this way it would not be profitable.
I am producer of organic pineapple, agronomist and producer this fruit since 2001 and have tried to achieve positive effects of floral induction and other natural options have failed, induction of flowering in pineapple is decisive to achieve close 98-99% effectiveness of floral induction is mandatory, however when this practice is not efficient and is achieved only 90% is not business, it cannot produce organic pineapple, or the price would have to rise proportionally, we have many lost by disease, insects and the high cost of organic inputs.
It's a shame to stop producing so exquisite and healthy pineapple.
4.Do you have any other thoughts on the necessity of ethylene gas in production of organic pineapples?:
In Costa Rica about 50 000 hectares of conventional pineapples are grown, and less than 1000 hectares organic pineapple, and many of these are aimed at the industry.
If we cannot use the ethylene we could not produce organic pineapple, and the market would lose the opportunity to consume these. Producing this pineapple is not easy so the few existing areas, without the ethylene would be impossible to do.
I think that NOSB put out the list of approved ethylene should ensure that there are alternative substitutes natural inputs not go against projects close existing organic pineapple.

Comment to classify: Inerts. Beyond Pesticides strongly opposes the proposed annotation of the listings for so-called "inert" ingredients in a way that abdicates NOSB responsibility for reviewing any synthetic substance used in organic. "Inert" ingredients in pesticide products are often neither chemically nor biologically inert. They can have toxic properties that may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). The Crops and Livestock Subcommittees have proposed to allow all chemicals listed on EPA's Safer Chemical Ingredients List to be used as "inert" ingredients in organic production. The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

Policy and Procedures Manual Revisions. Beyond Pesticides opposes revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual (PPM) that take power away from the NOSB and the public and reduce transparency in oversight of organic production. The law gives independent powers to the NOSB because of concerns that USDA would not honor organic principles. But the revisions take power away from the NOSB and create increased secrecy in the decision making process and less transparency of information used. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

Ancillary Substances. Beyond Pesticides opposes all three proposals on ancillary substances -microorganisms, pectin, and yeast- because they are inconsistent with OFPA and the process adopted by the NOSB for review of synthetic substances. Ancillary substances -those ingredients within ingredients that generally do not appear on labels- must, according to both OFPA and NOSB policy, be reviewed according to OFPA criteria. Instead, the Handling Subcommittee appears to be allowing all those currently in use, as well as new chemicals in the same functional class, and allowing toxic chemicals like formaldehyde to be added to organic food. The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.

Micronutrient Annotation. Beyond Pesticides opposes the annotation change proposed by the Crops Subcommittee (CS) because it encourages the use of synthetic micronutrients without evidence that demonstrates need. While the CS correctly points to methods other than soil testing to document soil deficiency, we dis Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Matthew Genaze --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify:
  Inerts. "Inert" ingredients in pesticide products are often neither chemically nor biologically inert. They can have toxic properties that may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). The Crops and Livestock Subcommittees have proposed to allow all chemicals listed on EPA's Safer Chemical Ingredients List to be used as "inert" ingredients in organic production. The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

Comment to classify: Good government requires that regulations be backed up by reference to legal criteria. Natural (nonsynthetic) materials that
are prohibited in organic crop production are listed on 205.602. Some of the materials on 602 are prohibited from use in
organic production directly by OFPA, and others, it appears, are listed based on common sense. Therefore, it is pleasing to
see that several of the materials on 602 have been supported by checklists. Before the next meeting, such justification
should be produced for the remaining materials. Finally, although tobacco dust/nicotine sulfate is no longer available for sale
in the United States, it should remain on 602 to discourage use of homemade tobacco dust. Comment to classify: The revision to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual is just another way to water down organic standards. The US govt. is spending way too much time trying to weaken our organic regulations instead of strengthening them. Pretty soon there won't be any difference in organic foods and foods loaded with toxic chemicals. The USDA is beholden to the chemical industry and is now going all out to weaken organic standards. This is wrong!!

So, I oppose revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual (PPM) that take power away from the NOSB and the public and reduce transparency in oversight of organic production. The law gives independent powers to the NOSB because of concerns that USDA would not honor organic principles. But the revisions take power away from the NOSB and create increased secrecy in the decision making process and less transparency of information used. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected. Comment to classify: We are pleased to note that the NOSB subcommittee is in favor of allowing synthetically extracted humic acids to be used in organic agriculture. Humic acid are being extracted using benign alkali solutions from a variety of natural organic humate deposits. These products have been standardized by many international organizations including Humic Products Trade Association in USA. Alkali extracted as well as biologically extracted humic acid products have been going through rigorous review by Organic Materials Review Institute and their experts have allowed their listing for use in organic food production. We request that use of synthetic extracted humic products be continued to be allowed for use in organic foodproduction.

the ONLY reason i have started to garden now, is because of all the pesticides people use on food.. i don't want to eat that and i won't.. enough is enough..

Comment to classify:

Dear Decision Maker,

Please keep organic strong. As a consumer, I have a right to a strong organic label. It is my right to know about the food I purchase and eat.
The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."
The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.
"Soil deficiency must be demonstrated by verifiable site-specific documentation that is accompanied by a plan for building soil that provides adequate nutrition through soil-building practices and organic inputs.
Thank you for your consideration

Comment to classify: . The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."
Policy and Procedures Manual Revisions. Beyond Pesticides opposes revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual (PPM) that take power away from the NOSB and the public and reduce transparency in oversight of organic production. The law gives independent powers to the NOSB because of concerns that USDA would not honor organic principles. But the revisions take power away from the NOSB and create increased secrecy in the decision making process and less transparency of information used. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

Ancillary Substances. Beyond Pesticides opposes all three proposals on ancillary substances -microorganisms, pectin, and yeast- because they are inconsistent with OFPA and the process adopted by the NOSB for review of synthetic substances. Ancillary substances -those ingredients within ingredients that generally do not appear on labels- must, according to both OFPA and NOSB policy, be reviewed according to OFPA criteria. Instead, the Handling Subcommittee appears to be allowing all those currently in use, as well as new chemicals in the same functional class, and allowing toxic chemicals like formaldehyde to be added to organic food. The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.
Micronutrient Annotation. Beyond Pesticides opposes the annotation change proposed by the Crops Subcommittee (CS) because it encourages the use of synthetic micronutrients without evidence that demonstrates need. While the CS correctly points to methods other than soil testing to document soil deficiency, we disagree with the CS' allowance use of synthetic micronutrients without on-site documentation. Beyond Pesticides supports a different restriction, "Soil deficiency must be demonstrated by verifiable site-specific documentation that is accompanied by a plan for building soil that provides adequate nutrition through soil-building practices and organic inputs."
We ask that you submit comments on as many issues and materials as you can by the October 8, 2015 deadline. For help crafting your comments, view Beyond Pesticides' commenting guide.

Comment to classify: Organic practices follow tough standards that do not compromise the health of people and the planet. Let's grow the organic food label as a symbol that honors this tradition. The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) violated the federal rulemaking process when it changed established procedures for reviewing the potential hazards and need for allowed synthetic and prohibited natural substances used in producing organic food.
The NOSB, intended to safeguard the integrity of the organic food label, was created by Congress with independent authorities that operate outside the discretion of the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA).
Please protect the integrity of the organic label, the law, and the standards-setting process. Protect NOSB's Independent Authorities from USDA Interference. The USDA MUST put a moratorium on changes announced in the September 16, 2013 Federal Register (78 FR 56811, National Organic Program-Sunset Process) and in the USDA Organic Insider on March 6, 2014, and allow the public the opportunity to comment. Comment to classify: PLEASE:
: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) DO NOT change the listing of "inerts," ; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.
, "Soil deficiency must be demonstrated by verifiable site-specific documentation that is accompanied by a plan for building soil that provides adequate nutrition through soil-building practices and organic inputs."

. Our future is only as healthy as organic.

Thank you!

Comment to classify: The Global Organization for EPA and DHA Omega3s (GOED) is an association of processors, refiners, manufacturers, distributors, marketers, retailers and supporters of products containing eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) omega3 fatty acids. GOED's membership represents a broad range of businesses, from small entrepreneurs to multinational food companies. The Organization's objectives are to educate consumers about the health benefits of EPA/DHA and to collaborate with government groups, the healthcare community and the industry on issues related to omega3s, while setting high standards for our business sector.

GOED has learned that the National Organic Standards Board (NOSB), at its upcoming public meeting (October 26-29, 2015), is going to consider a proposal to relist fish oil in 7 CFR 205.606, the list of nonorganically produced agricultural products allowed as ingredients in or on processed products labeled as "organic." Consumers who prefer organic products should have access to products made with non-organically produced fish oil, since organic fish oil does not currently exist. Thus said, GOED appreciates the opportunity to provide information to the NOSB in order for it to make an informed decision at its upcoming meeting. GOED will first provide comments related to the NOSB's six questions posed in advance of its spring meeting. Then, GOED will provide comments on the effects of fish oil on human health (i.e. efficacy and safety).

For GOED's full comments, please see attached file. Comment to classify: I would like to comment on the integrity of organic products. According to the Organic Foods Production Act, a synthetic substance may only be allowed for use in organic production if it meets the following criteria [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(B)]:

It contains an active synthetic ingredient in the following categories: copper and sulfur compounds; toxins derived from bacteria; pheromones, soaps, horticultural oils, fish emulsions, treated seed, vitamins and minerals; livestock parasiticides and medicines and production aids including netting, tree wraps and seals, insect traps, sticky barriers, row covers, and equipment cleansers.
It contains synthetic inert ingredients that are not classified by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency as inerts of toxicological concern.

Additionally, it must be fully established that the use of the substance [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(A)]

would not be harmful to human health or the environment;
is necessary to the production or handling of the final product because natural substitutes are not available; and
is consistent with organic farming and handling (see the NOSB's Principles of Organic Production and Handling). Thank you for your consideration in this regard>

Comment to classify: This comment is concerning regulation 205.605(b) synthetics allowed--ethylene gas spraying on produce.
I have allergic contact dermatitis with exposure to propylene glycol (PG) and polyethylene glycol (PEG). This means that even with miniscule exposure, I develop a rash, fluid-filled blisters and stomach and bowel distress. You may already know that PG and PEG are ubiquitous, petroleum-based chemicals used extensively in the production of food, pharmaceuticals and personal care products. Their versatility as softening agents, preservatives, humectants, emulsifiers and solvents means they can be used in virtually any/all processed foods, labeled and unlabeled. Because of this fact and the fact that PG is sprayed on many fruits and vegetables, I buy limited processed food and all organic produce. The reality that synthetic ethylene gas is now allowed to be sprayed on tropical and citrus organic fruits and vegetables is extremely troubling to me because I rely heavily on the assurance that USDA organic produce is safe for me.

I have done enough research to know that ethylene is a natural plant hormone. I also know that the chemical formulas for natural ethylene gas and synthetically produced ethylene gas are supposedly the same. Even though I am not a chemist, I know this is not true. My skin does not lie and it has not allowed me to eat organic bananas, tomatoes or pineapple since my PG diagnosis, even though I was able to eat them before the development of my allergy. My arguments in defense of this position are as follows: 1) A correlation can be made to generic vs. trade name medicines. Pharmaceutical companies and doctors (via medical insurance companies) say the generic is the same drug. The reality is, however, that the drugs are bioequivalent in that they have the same dosage form, safety assurance, strength, route of administration, quality, performance characteristics and intended use. Pharmaceutical companies are required to explain the components of the generic drugs, but NOT how they are made. The FDA has a broad definition of biological equivalence. For example, a generic's maximum concentration of active ingredients in the blood must not fall more than 20% below or 25% above the brand name. This leaves a potential concentration of 45% by that measure among generics labeled as being the same. 2) I believe the same logic can be applied to the man-made ethylene. HOW PURE IS THE ETHYLENE BEING MADE COMMERCIALLY--ESPECIALLY THE ETHYLENE BEING MADE AND USED IN THE FOREIGN COUNTRIES WHERE MANY OF OUR TROPICAL FRUITS COME FROM? It is very likely that trace amounts of other things get into the mix, especially with multiple processes going on in producing and applying it. The fact that the same molecule may be perceived differently at different concentrations is a distinct possibility. Other sources of ethylene, such as exhaust fumes during transit, can also drastically raise the concentration of ethylene Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Kerry Kuzak --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. Comment to classify: NOSB/Hydroponics and Aquaponics Task Force: I support the continued allowance of Hydroponics and Aquaponics as part of
the USDA Certified Organic Program. I believe the main point for consumers is to have animal and plant products that are
raised/grown without the use of any chemicals, pesticides, steroids, man-made additives, etc....In other words, only all natural
inputs.
It seems a small handful of people are pushing for the requirement of using soil and are against hydroponics and aquaponics.
If a grower can get all the nutrients that the plant needs into the water (from all natural sources), and he/she ends up with a
clean, healthy and nutritious plant, why should it specifically need to be grown in soil? It doesn't make sense to require the use
of soil. Requiring the use of soil seems more like an opinion, and a preference for some people, possibly to keep old traditions
in place?In that case, what else should be reviewed? Maybe metal shovels should not be allowed in organic farming, only
shovels carved out of wood?

Many years ago, the USDA recognized that modern growing methods need to be supported to keep pace with feeding
the ever expanding population. Hydroponics and aquaponics fit into this category. They fit in with the many other agricultural
advancements that have been developed through the years (and are approved for organic farming) such as tractors,
mechanized farm implements, irrigation systems and greenhouses. I urge the USDA to stay on track with this understanding
of the need for progress.

Here is an interesting comparison:
The positive affects of these growing methods are far-reaching. I spoke to a gentleman the other day who has developed
a solar powered 'closed loop' aquaponics system that he hopes to get into the hands of farmers in third world countries to help
fight starvation. His system consists of raising crickets, feeding them to fish, the water that the fish swim in flows to vegetable
plants, which flourish on the nutrients provided by the fish waste. I realize these farmers in the third world countries are not
trying to become 'certified organic' (they just want to survive), however I believe it is great example of the ultimate method of
Organic Farming. So what would the USA proponents for 'having to grow in soil' say to these farmers? "It should not be
done because _______" WHY? What would be the argument?

Please do not let a small vocal group stop what is already proven to be a viable and efficient way to produce safe healthy
crops for the ever growing population. Banning the use of Hydroponics and Aquaponics for Organic certification would
be a direct negative affect to many small growers throughout North America. Comment to classify: Inerts.
I strongly oppose the proposed annotation of the listings for so-called "inert" ingredients in a way that abdicates NOSB responsibility for reviewing any synthetic substance used in organic. "Inert" ingredients in pesticide products are often neither chemically nor biologically inert. They can have toxic properties that may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). The Crops and Livestock Subcommittees have proposed to allow all chemicals listed on EPA's Safer Chemical Ingredients List to be used as "inert" ingredients in organic production. The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

Policy and Procedures Manual Revisions.
I oppose revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual (PPM) that take power away from the NOSB and the public and reduce transparency in oversight of organic production. The law gives independent powers to the NOSB because of concerns that USDA will not honor organic principles. But the revisions take power away from the NOSB and create increased secrecy in the decision making process and less transparency of information used. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, of an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and demand an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

Ancillary Substances.
I oppose all three proposals on ancillary substances -microorganisms, pectin, and yeast- because they are inconsistent with OFPA and the process adopted by the NOSB for review of synthetic substances. Ancillary substances -those ingredients within ingredients that generally do not appear on labels- must, according to both OFPA and NOSB policy, be reviewed according to OFPA criteria. Instead, the Handling Subcommittee appears to be allowing all those currently in use, as well as new chemicals in the same functional class, and allowing toxic chemicals like formaldehyde to be added to organic food. The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.

Micronutrient Annotation.
I oppose the annotation change proposed by the Crops Subcommittee (CS) because it encourages the use of synthetic micronutrients without evidence that demonstrates either need or safety. While the CS correctly points to methods other than soil testing to document soil deficiency, I disagree with the CS' allowance use of synthetic micronutrie Metadata: - Organization: None - Submitter Type: None - Name: Ellen Koivisto --- Classify the AUTHOR of the above public comment as exactly ONE of these categories: **org** - Large corporations, industry associations, trade groups, or organizational entities **citizen** - Individual ordinary citizens, residents, or community members without professional affiliation **expert** - Academics, researchers, small/local businesses, industry experts, technical specialists **lobbyist** - Political consultants, registered lobbyists, advocacy groups, or professional campaigners **undecided** - ONLY if truly anonymous with no identifying info or completely unclear authorship Decision guidance: - Use ALL available context clues (tone, language, content, structure, signatures, letterheads) - Look for: organizational letterhead, academic titles, business names, lobbying language, personal stories, signatures - Large company or trade association or group → org - Generic "concerned citizen" with personal story/opinion → citizen (NOT undecided) - Individual small business owners → expert (not org) - Professional advocates or political operatives → lobbyist - AVOID undecided unless genuinely impossible to determine - make your best inference from the text Be decisive. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.

Soil deficiency must be demonstrated by verifiable site-specific documentation that is accompanied by a plan for building soil that provides adequate nutrition through soil-building practices and organic inputs. Comment to classify: Dear Board Members,

I have always been willing to pay higher prices for Organic food because I believe that it is better for my health and the environment. I have severe chemical sensitivities. I want to believe that National Organic Standards can be trusted. I am writing to ask you to please:
1. Reject the proposed annotation change.
2. Do not change the lists of inerts approved in 2012.
3. Remove NPEs from being used.

USDA Organic labels need to represent food that can be trusted. We need to know that there is a Board Member group that will not allow harmful chemicals to be sprayed, or unlisted additives added to our food. We do not want to be in the dark about what goes into our bodies. We pay more BECAUSE WE CARE. PLEASE CONTINUE TO BE A GROUP THAT CARES!!!

Thank you for listening,
D. Grady

Comment to classify: The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

"Inerts" are only labeled this way because they are not the ingredient actively responsible for treating the targeted organism in any given agricultural product. The label indicates nothing about the "inert" compound's actual toxicity and dangers associated with its use, giving end users a false sense of safety when reading this term on a label. "Inerts" should require the same degree of rigorous review that any chemical gets from the NOSB for meeting OFPA standards. Comment to classify:
I strongly oppose the proposed annotation of the listings for so-called "inert" ingredients in a way that abdicates NOSB responsibility for reviewing any synthetic substance used in organic. "Inert" ingredients in pesticide products are often neither chemically nor biologically inert. They can have toxic properties that may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). The Crops and Livestock Subcommittees have proposed to allow all chemicals listed on EPA's Safer Chemical Ingredients List to be used as "inert" ingredients in organic production. The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

Comment to classify: Please work faithfully to keep our National Organic Standards as strong as possible. I feel that all of your agenda
items listed on the email to which I am responding, by "Consumer Reports Greener Choices" are worthy of serious

a package so the customer could examine it. If plastic is used, it should definitely be clear, not pink to hide decay.
