for the contamination. Actually I don't feel that living organisms should be patentable, but that's yet another issue. Comment to classify:
Keeping organic standards as they were originally set, based on massive consumer support, is important to enable consumers to continue to have freedom of choice over the foods we purchase and eat.  Without continuing an organic standard that does not include GMO foods, consumers are left without any possible way to determine the nature and etiology of their foods.  Little attention has been given to the changes in immune system function that is more likely than not created by the new proteins and related cell biochemistry changes that come from introducing new genes into foods.  It is shameful that a country that touts its superiority due to freedoms, is continuing to take away freedoms of right to know and right to chose what we put into our bodies.

Comment to classify: Inerts. I strongly oppose the proposed annotation of the listings for so-called "inert" ingredients in a way that abdicates NOSB responsibility for reviewing any synthetic substance used in organic. "Inert" ingredients in pesticide products are often neither chemically nor biologically inert. They can have toxic properties that may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). The Crops and Livestock Subcommittees have proposed to allow all chemicals listed on EPA's Safer Chemical Ingredients List to be used as "inert" ingredients in organic production. The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

Policy and Procedures Manual Revisions. I oppose revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual (PPM) that take power away from the NOSB and the public and reduce transparency in oversight of organic production. The law gives independent powers to the NOSB because of concerns that USDA would not honor organic principles. But the revisions take power away from the NOSB and create increased secrecy in the decision making process and less transparency of information used. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

Ancillary Substances. I oppose all three proposals on ancillary substances -microorganisms, pectin, and yeast- because they are inconsistent with OFPA and the process adopted by the NOSB for review of synthetic substances. Ancillary substances -those ingredients within ingredients that generally do not appear on labels- must, according to both OFPA and NOSB policy, be reviewed according to OFPA criteria. Instead, the Handling Subcommittee appears to be allowing all those currently in use, as well as new chemicals in the same functional class, and allowing toxic chemicals like formaldehyde to be added to organic food. The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.

Micronutrient Annotation. I oppose the annotation change proposed by the Crops Subcommittee (CS) because it encourages the use of synthetic micronutrients without evidence that demonstrates need. While the CS correctly points to methods other than soil testing to document soil deficiency, we disagree with the CS' allowance use of synthetic micronutrients without on-site documentation. Comment to classify: Subject: Support for continued listing of Ethylene for postharvest ripening of tropical fruit.

Reference: 205.605(b) allowed for postharvest ripening of tropical fruit and degreening of citrus.

Dear NOSB members.
Dole Tropical Products Latin America Ltd. , the leading grower and exporter of organic bananas to the United States,
introduces these comments in favor of the motion to maintain Ethylene on the National List for use in the ripening of
tropical fruit postharvest.

The use of ethylene gas to ripen organic bananas is an essential ingredient in order to be able to supply the U.S. market.
Our Company currently sources and produces organic bananas in Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia to supply customers
in the United States. In order to maintain this activity and the jobs created by the organic banana industry in the tropical
countries mentioned, we are in full agreement with the Handling Subcommittee's proposal that Ethylene remain on the
National List.

In addition, this proposal will allow the United States regulations to continue to be aligned with organic standards such as
those of the European Union, Canada and Codex which all allow the use of ethylene for the purpose mentioned.

We strongly suggest that the full board approve the subcommittee's unanimous vote on the motion against the removal
of ethylene from the National List.

Sincerely yours,

Rudy Amador
Director, Product Stewardship and Sustainable Agriculture
Dole Tropical Products Latin America Ltd.
Escazu, San Jose, Costa Rica

Comment to classify: Glycerin is an important ingredient used in our herb and spice pastes for its water binding, textural, and natural preservation properties. The letter from the Organic Trade Association to the Handling Committee, dated April 7, 2015, suggested insufficient supply of organic glycerin. From our research we too have found extremely limited supply of organic glycerin in the quality, quantity and form needed for our products. A rule change making organic glycerin compulsory, particularly in the made with organic category, would increase demand and almost certainly leave us in a situation of non-supply.

Secondly the proposed rule change to reclassify glycerin as agricultural will undoubtedly place further strain on current supplies of agricultural glycerin whether made by fermentation or hydrolysis.

Thirdly, a significant proportion of glycerin is sourced from soy and therefore not suitable for certain applications due to the allergenic nature of soy. This adds a further complication and supply restriction for customer who require non-soy sources of organic glycerin and agricultural glycerin.

Comment to classify: I am a transplant patient and Organic foods are extremely important to keeping my tranplanted kidney for as long as possible. Below are why Organics Standards staying the way they are if not improving are important to me.

According to the Organic Foods Production Act, a synthetic substance may only be allowed for use in organic production if it meets the following criteria [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(B)]:

It contains an active synthetic ingredient in the following categories: copper and sulfur compounds; toxins derived from bacteria; pheromones, soaps, horticultural oils, fish emulsions, treated seed, vitamins and minerals; livestock parasiticides and medicines and production aids including netting, tree wraps and seals, insect traps, sticky barriers, row covers, and equipment cleansers.

It contains synthetic inert ingredients that are not classified by the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency as inerts of toxicological concern.

Additionally, it must be fully established that the use of the substance [7 USC 6517(c)(1)(A)]

would not be harmful to human health or the environment;

is necessary to the production or handling of the final product because natural substitutes are not available; and

is consistent with organic farming and handling (see the NOSB's Principles of Organic Production and Handling). Comment to classify: National Organic Standards Board

2017 Sunset, Sulfur Dioxide on National List at 7 CFR 205.605(b)

Comments of Organic Vintners, Inc., Boulder, Colorado

Organic Vintners, Inc., founded in 2001 and based in Boulder, Colorado, imports and distributes wines made from 100% organic grapes. Our wines come from the United States, Europe, Latin America and New Zealand. Organic Vintners understands that the National Organic Standards Board is reviewing the listing of sulfur dioxide (sulfites) on the National List in 7 CFR 205.605(b). This listing is set to expire on June 27, 2017, unless the Board votes to extend the listing. This listing allows sulfur dioxide "for use only in wine labeled 'made with organic grapes.'" The total sulfite concentration may not exceed 100 ppm.

Organic Vintners strongly supports continuing this listing, and requests the National Organic Standards Board to vote to keep this allowance for sulfur dioxide. Sulfur dioxide (sulfites) is a naturally occurring by-product of fermentation. In addition to the sulfites that occur naturally, the wine industry the world over adds sulfites to wine in the winery to control unwanted bacteria and to preserve the quality and shelf life of the wine.

It is vital to the community of organic wine grape organic growers and the organic wine industry as a whole both in the United States and throughout the world that this allowance for sulfur dioxide be continued. The reason is that the wholly "organic" winemakers, those that are willing to produce their wine without the benefits of added sulfites, remain a very small group within the industry. Even with the "organic" label, their wines have not achieved a significant market share. Some would attribute this, at least in part, to the lack of added sulfites. The vast majority of wine grapes that are grown organically for organic consumers in the United States go into wine that is under organic certification but is labeled "made with organic grapes," instead of "organic," because sulfites are added. Those organic winemakers, the vast majority, believe it is absolutely necessary to add sulfites to preserve the stability and quality of the wine.

If organic winemakers adding sulfites could no longer make the organic claim under the NOP, "made with organic grapes," for their wines, this would decimate the existing organic wine market. It would mean that the only wine left on the market that could make any type of "organic" claim would be the wholly organic wines. Because only a handful of wineries occupy that small segment of the industry, there would be a vastly diminished market for organically grown grapes. Comment to classify: Subject: Support for continued listing of plastic mulch and covers for organic agriculture.

Reference: 205.601(b) As herbicides, weed barriers, as applicable. (2) Mulches. (ii) Plastic mulch and
covers (petroleum-based other than polyvinyl chloride (PVC)).

Dear NOSB members.

Dole Tropical Products Latin America Ltd. , the leading grower and exporter of organic pineapples to the United States,
introduces these comments in favor of the motion to maintain plastic mulch and covers on the National List for use as a
mulch to control weeds in organic production.

Our Company sources and produces organic pineapples cultivated in Costa Rica. The organic pineapple farms must use
plastic mulches to control weeds, as well as to allow for the growth of healthy root systems that can tolerate the damage
caused by soil pests and diseases.

Since pineapples grow directly in the fields with direct exposure to sunlight, the lack of weed control is a situation that can
drastically harm organic pineapple cultivation; the many weeds present in the tropical fields will quickly overtake the pineapple
plants causing complete loss of the cultivated plantation.

Co-benefits such as pest and disease tolerance would be lost without the use of plastic mulch causing further losses and/or
the need to use other materials and practices to control these additional production limitations.

Alternatives such as the use of bioplastics for mulches have not proven successful, as the plastic mulch must remain in place
for over two years for the entire crop cycle. In Costa Rica, the plastic mulch is removed by the farm and recycled or used as
an energy source in cement kilns, as approved by the Government. Environmental impact form the use of these mulches is
very limited and is far outweighed by the environmental benefits afforded. Plastic mulch is the most effective method to control
soil erosion in pineapple cultivation (erosion rates are basically zero), and the farming of organic pineapples actually lists this
as one of the most important and sustainable practices for this crop.

Dole Tropical Products fully agrees with the subcommittee's vote against the motion to remove plastic mulch and covers
from 205.601(b). The use of plastic mulch is an essential practice for the cultivation of organic pineapples in Costa Rica and
elsewhere and the crop could not be produced without it use; farms both large and small would have to convert to
conventional agriculture in order to produce a sustainable pineapple crop.

Sincerely yours,

Rudy Amador
Director, Product Stewardship and Sustainable Agriculture
Dole Tropical Products Latin America Ltd.
Escazu, San Jose, Costa Rica
rudy.e.amador@dole.com
October 6th, 2015

Comment to classify: I AM VERY CONCERNED, IF THE NOSB STARTS TO LABEL FOR BIG BUSINESS GREED AND LIE---THEN IT NEEDS TO BE GONE, AS IT CAN NO LONGER BE TRUSTED!!!! Major issues before the fall 2015 NOSB include:
The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."
The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.
The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.
I oppose the annotation change proposed by the Crops Subcommittee (CS) because it encourages the use of synthetic micronutrients without evidence that demonstrates need. While the CS correctly points to methods other than soil testing to document soil deficiency, I disagree with the CS' allowance use of synthetic micronutrients without on-site documentation. I AGREE WITH Beyond Pesticides, WHICH supports a different restriction, "Soil deficiency must be demonstrated by verifiable site-specific documentation that is accompanied by a plan for building soil that provides adequate nutrition through soil-building practices and organic inputs."

Comment to classify: Natural Flavors

Natural Flavors are essential for a strong Organic market, because consumers demand is for products flavored in ways that only Natural Flavors can bring to many products.

Some Natural Flavors can be Organic, some can NOT. Many can not. The OTA petition to bring commercial availability into the requirements will enable use of Organic Natural Flavors when they are available and will allow use of Natural Flavors when Organic alternatives are not available.

To disallow use of Natural flavors when there are no organic alternatives will decimate Organic products.

Eliminate Natural Flavors entirely from 605 and that giant sucking sound you hear will be Organic products being replaced by "Natural" products.

The OTA's petition that brings commercial availability into play is a strong step forward strengthening Organic foods.

Thank you for all your efforts.

Comment to classify: I am writing to support the use of humic substances in Organic Agriculture. I am doing this in my capacity as a nutritionist who
has conducted animal research with humic and Fulvic acids at the university. I am also a member of the International Humic
Substances Society (IHSS) and a scientific committee member of the Humic Products and Trade Association. In my research
work, I have extracted humic and Fulvic acids from raw humates nearly from all over the world. The United States is by far, one
of the few countries in the world that harbors some of the finest soil-base humic substances. Unlike, other parts of
the world where these products are located mainly in riverbeds, lakes and caves where they're prone to exposure to acid rain,
GMO's and runoff from chemically fertilized farm lands, ours are buried away in the pristine wildness of the environment. As
farms are gradually over-farmed with chemical-base products, recharging of these farms with humic substances (organically) to
make them sustainable would become inevitable if we want to maintain our leadership as the bread basket of the world. Also, as
the demand for wholesome organically produced foods increase, it would be advantageous for us to have these unique
resources in our arsenal in order to become competitive in the world. Whether we are using them in crops or for future
stimulation of rumen microbes the same way as we currently do in soils, we would generate organic foods that are very healthy
for people and therefore provide us with an enviable market share of the world economy. For these and many other reasons, I
support the use of humic substances in organic agriculture. Comment to classify: It's critical that consumers are able to make healthy food choice selections.

Labelilng GMO's is a bare minimum right to know situation. Stand with consumers and not with giant food corporations and their supporters who are fighting so hard and throwing so much money at keeping this basic level of information about our food off labels and consumer level product information. Clearly, the food giants know GMO's are not in our best interest, or why would they be fighting so hard to keep this non-GMO designation requirement from getting passed into law/reguations.

Furthermore, knowing when items are labeled "Organic", should also mean specific standards of how the food was grown. That toxic chemical pesticides were not used, such as Round-up, or any of the other known cancer causing formulas.

Please act and vote your conscious, stand with the consumer (you are one too!) and support visibility, integrity in food labeling practices.

Thanks,

Comment to classify: Dear Sir/Madam:

I am a retired civil servant who has been eating only organic food for several years. I am writing to ask that you do not weaken organic standards in any way. To be more specific:

1)Do not permit the chemicals listed on the EPA's "Safer Chemical Ingredients" list to receive a blanket listing as "inert ingredients" in organic production. Many of these compounds may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). In fact, they may have toxic properties. Instead of allowing such substances indiscriminately, the National Organic Standards Board (NOSB) should evaluate them according to the review plan which the board unanimously approved in 2012.

2)Do not permit revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual that take power from the NOSB or reduce transparency in the supervision of organic production. The OFPA grants the NOSB sole authority to, among other things, recommend adding or removing materials from the National List. Please do not weaken that authority, and please do not increase secrecy as to how decisions are made.

3)Reject the proposal by the Crops Subcommittee regarding micro-nutrient annotation because this proposal makes it easier to use synthetic micro-nutrients without evidence that such micro-nutrients are needed. Before synthetic micro-nutrients are used, there should be specific documentation of soil deficiency at each site, and a detailed explanation of why natural soil-building practices and organic nutrients are inadequate for remedying the deficiency.

4)Reject the proposals for the following ancillary substances: micro-organisms, pectin, and yeast. The proposals are not based on evaluations of the substances according to criteria established by the OFPA. Thus they violate the Act. These proposals should also be rejected because each of them would allow additional ancillaries without any review at all. This is not only a violation of the Act, but an insult to those who trust the organic label. It debases the concept of "organic".

Rather than weaken organic standards, the NOSB should strengthen them. If it was not in the food my mom prepared, please do not permit it in the (organic) food I eat.

Yours truly,
Matthew Lipschik

Comment to classify: Inerts. I oppose the proposed annotation of the listings for so-called "inert" ingredients in a way that abdicates NOSB responsibility for reviewing any synthetic substance used in organic. "Inert" ingredients in pesticide products are often neither chemically nor biologically inert. They can have toxic properties that may not meet the standards of the Organic Foods Production Act (OFPA). The Crops and Livestock Subcommittees have proposed to allow all chemicals listed on EPA's Safer Chemical Ingredients List to be used as "inert" ingredients in organic production. The NOSB should: (1) Reject the proposed annotation change; (2) Tell USDA not to change the listing of "inerts," unanimously approved by the NOSB in 2012; (3) Implement the review plan approved unanimously by the board in 2012; (4) Amend the listing to remove toxic nonylphenol ethoxylates (NPEs); and (5) Make changes only to hasten the review of so-called "inerts."

Policy and Procedures Manual Revisions. I oppose revisions to the NOSB Policy and Procedures Manual (PPM) that take power away from the NOSB and the public and reduce transparency in oversight of organic production. The law gives independent powers to the NOSB because of concerns that USDA would not honor organic principles. But the revisions take power away from the NOSB and create increased secrecy in the decision making process and less transparency of information used. The NOSB must demand to vote on changes, based on a redlined version, an annotated table of contents that indicates which sections have been moved or changed, and an explanation and justification of each change. Changes that take power away from the NOSB or reduce transparency should be rejected.

Ancillary Substances. I oppose all three proposals on ancillary substances -microorganisms, pectin, and yeast- because they are inconsistent with OFPA and the process adopted by the NOSB for review of synthetic substances. Ancillary substances -those ingredients within ingredients that generally do not appear on labels- must, according to both OFPA and NOSB policy, be reviewed according to OFPA criteria. Instead, the Handling Subcommittee appears to be allowing all those currently in use, as well as new chemicals in the same functional class, and allowing toxic chemicals like formaldehyde to be added to organic food. The NOSB must reject all three ancillary ingredients proposals and demand that all ancillary ingredients be evaluated according to organic standards in the law.

Micronutrient Annotation. I oppose the annotation change proposed by the Crops Subcommittee (CS) because it encourages the use of synthetic micronutrients without evidence that demonstrates need. While the CS correctly points to methods other than soil testing to document soil deficiency, we disagree with the CS' allowance use of synthetic micronutrients without on-site documentation.
